Posted: June 26, 2014
												On normal difficulty this game can be completed in around 3 to 4 hours. Factor that in when deciding if the price is worth it.Having said that, this is a disturbing little jaunt into the Slender Man nightmare. The creators deserve a pat on the back for making such a picturesque and harrowing atmosphere.Gameplay is extremely straight forward: explore, read letters, do a certain thing a certain number of times, and (most important of all) RUN AWAY.I would love to see more of the same, except this time with a decent budget and a better variety of tasks. Puzzles, riddles, maybe a little combat with 'infected' people. All in all, this is worth throwing a few quid at. Play it in the dark with head phones on. Times I shrieked or squealed (rough estimate): 10.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I pre-ordered Slender: The Arrival last year after enjoying Slender: The 8 Pages. As with every game there is good and bad, however mostly bad for this game.First of all the good:The game has a very good horror atmosphere and you are likely to get scared at several points throughout the game. The story was well thought out and when it's sunny in the game, the area does look beautiful. For an indie game the graphics are well done, even on the lowest settings. Also Slender isn't your only enemy too. The music also has variaty too, which is something you don't see much in games. This is where the good ends.The bad:As you can see on the "popular user-defined tags" one of them is "Walking Simulator". This describes the game pretty well in my opinion. The game also heavily relies on jump scares, which gets repetitive and you just expect it after a while. The only level which actually scared me was level 3-however you soon become aware of the tactics used by the proxy in this level (I won't reveal much more about this NPC as it will spoil the game's twist which I thought was great!). The game is also INCREDIBLY short. LIke most people, I completed it in a little over an hour on Normal mode (keep in mind I am TERRIBLE at games) however when I decided to play through the game for a second time shortly after activating the product on steam instead I did notice they added in a little extra which was great, however it didn't really do much to increase the game's length. The levels are reptitive, it's always collect or do 8 ect. ect..Overall I suggest only buying it on sale (like it is as of me writing this review- it's £1.74 right now) as it's great for a night in with friends and I do regulary make guests at my house play it and it also comes with achievments, steam trading cards and occational contests (the recent one being the Easter Egg contest) however the original price I paid to pre-order this game (which was £20 I think? Can't remember) wasn't enough, even with all the extras.Would I buy the sequel? Yes, but only if the price is reasonable and there is variaty. However Slender: The Arrival is a poor game with very little replay value and you'd probably find yourself quiting about half way through.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Slender the Arrival is a constant reminder of what was and what sould've been for the games predecesor and the game its self. Its few and far between scares, lack of clearly visible story, and lack of any additional content. Make Slender the Arrival a tough buy for any fan of trhe origional Slender the Eight Pages fan, and fans of survival horror games in general. Performance wise, the game is a mixed bag, with a quad core i7, 2 gig nVidia GPU, and eight gigabytes of ram. I got between the pitiful realm of around twenty FPS to what felt like about fourty. It is not a welly optomized game. With this in mind, the graphicaql quality of the game, maxed out on my rig, dosen't really meet the current bar for the genere. It's muddy, and lifeless, despite its seemingly large world. I got very few scares out of the game, and finished in about an hour or so, on easy. Raise the difficulty, and the game batters you. Glitches, unfair diffulcty curbs, and an overall bland narrarative. I was looking forward to this game, for some good scares with slightly upgrated visuals. I got almost no scares, little tension, and sub par performance. Buy this game if you must, butI do regret mu purchase.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Oh man. I wanted to like this game. I'd always heard how supremely creepy the Slender mythos was, and I'd heard good things about the Eight Pages when it was free on the web (though I'd never played it). Alas. Yes, there are a few decent jump scares, but that's about it. Honestly, the most frightening thing about the game is how hot it makes my computer run. I couldn't focus on the prologue because I was too busy wondering if my PC was going to catch fire. In terms of gameplay, there's not much to it. You run around, pick up or turn on things, and try not to die. Funny thing about that, though. Running wears you out pretty fast, or something - I don't know. It's hard to say. You'll be trying to run away from something, and then you're not running fast anymore, and then OH GOD IT'S ON MY FACE. Retry. Retry. Retry. Since key objects are - in most cases - randomly generated around each level, all you can really do is hope they spawn close enough so that you can activate them before whatever thing is after you tries to kill you. Sound like Outlast? It's a lot like Outlast. Except you can't hide from things, and as far as I can tell, turning off your flashlight doesn't dissuade them from running over and clawing your face. Fun! Except not. Also, about that story: you are someone, apparently, wearing a hoodie and recording everything, because found footage, or whatever. And it seems you're trying to find your friend, or something, who apparently is a nut case and likes to draw with chalk on every surface for hours at a time in big scribbly letters. You get hints of something or whatever, but that's about it. Despite a decent score, and a few pretty vistas throughout, this game is really not worth the hour or two it takes to complete it.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game could've been a really good horror game. Shame it was wasted. Slender: The Arrival is a "remake" of the original Slender game, which I found boring as hell, but tons of people praised it anyway. After it blew up, a company tried to make a Slender game, knowing it would sell. They were right about the selling. Unfortunately, there's not a lot to offer here.The game is incredibly short, I beat it in a sitting. You basically just wander through a forest and♥♥♥♥♥♥ and often times run away from things. The two "panic" levels included The Eight Pages, and some Generator start up thing. The Eight Pages part is your typical, lame, Slender thing where you find the pages in a poorly randomized world. It's okay, but there's not really a sense of urgency considering you can outrun him easily. The second part, the Generator section, was awful. You get chased by the human like thing who, like, chases you, sits on your face for 3 seconds, then leaves, I guess. I don't know if it was supposed to kill you, but it sure as hell didn't kill me. It's too easy and can be quickly done, first try. The rest of the game drags on in uninteresting walking phases, with a forest fire with Slendy trying to catch you. That's about it. There's a story somewhere in there, about you trying to find your friend, but it just didn't click well with me and all the Collectibles I found I immediately put them away and never looked at them.This game could've been something. It could've been a really soild horror game. Instead, it relies on the jumpscares and the "look I'm spooky I'm gonna get you" kinda stuff. I really wish millions of stupid kids never praised the original Slender game. If you're looking for a good horror game, don't bother. The 12 year old kids might think it's scary, but in all honesty, this game didn't make me flinch. The villain is a 10 foot tall guy with no face and a suit with ♥♥♥♥ing tentacles. If you think that's scary, you need mental help.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												As if Slender: The Eight Pages wasn't scary enough. Slender: The Arrival has taken the original concept of the horror game and took a few more steps further. The jump-scares are certainly worth it, now that you actually HAVE to worry about Slender Man grabbing you with his tenticles. Not only that, our tall friend has a little companion, which adds on to your worries. You are no longer looking at a bleak forest each time you play. You have different levels you can get to, let it be finding the original 8 pages or turning on generators. The atmosphere has certainly become creepier, and I absolutely love it. Not to mention, you have a back story to this whole thing. It isn't like in 8 pages where you are sent off on a quest to find 8 drawings for the heck of it. This game has been promising from the start, and I'm certainly thrilled to have bought it.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												If you like the Slenderman character. Cool. If you liked the original indie game Slender. Cool.Slender The Arrival is the sequel to the massively popular indie game by Parsec Productions. Which to be honest I wasn't too in to. The main problem with this game is how repetitive it is. Almost every level is finding a certain number of items, be it pages or generators. And that's pretty bad when there are only FIVE LEVELS.The game actually has more monsters that just Slenderman, which I commend them for. However, they are rarely seen ingame, which is slightly dissapointing. But for the levels they are on. It's a nice addition.So, overall. Slender: The Arrival isn't the worst horror game ever made, it's got really cool visuals and a decent atmosphere. But it's not the long quality experience that I expected from the game. For the price, you won't be that dissapointed. But it could be a lot better. I would say to give it a look, and judge it for yourself.

Posted: March 4, 2015
												Oooooh, Spooky Slenderman is coming to touch your butt with his ticklefingers!But seriously, this game looked half decent in the trailers and screenshots and what not, it looked like it could make the Slender games actually scary to me, if done right. But unfortuantley, this game is not done right, far from it.You're all familar with Slender right, the free horror game built with unity that was about you running away from the Slenderman, a tall white guy from Internet campfire stories, while collecting pages for some reason. It was ok I guess, despite it being the very defention of jumpscare fest, but it was atleast free. Not anymore. With Slender: The Arrival now you can get chased by a tall white man while collecting pages. But with prettier graphics!This game tries to set up a plot, starting out with you jogging threw the woods to a childhood friend's house, but when you get there she isn't there. Just a buttload of scribbles on the wall. You walk around for a while and eventually Slendypants pops his head up threw a window. Then you have to collect pages, that cause the Slenderman to attack you.First off, for a game that's trying so hard to set up a story, it does a pretty poor job at explaining what we're doing and why we're doing it. Why do we need these pages, what could these drawings by a 4-year old tell us, and why do we want them if they make Slendy attack you? Secondly, I don't really find Slenderman himself that scary, he's just a tall white guy to me,  so it might be  the fact that I'm also very tall and pale thats putting me off. If you were more enriched in the lore of Slenderman then I guess this could be scary. Maybe.But thirdly, and most importantly, the gameplay is just awful. I like to judge horror games partially by how much they can hold up after all the spooks end. Game's like Amnesia and Five Night's at Freddy's I managed to like as I did find them fun to play after I stopped being scared. But Slender isn't one of those games, every single level is walking around, collecting or turning on X of a certain object, while Slenderman jumpscares you, or on one level, you get chased by a human. Rather than running away, from it, you get to stand still for a second and flash your light at it stop it from running at you.Over and over and over. This game was so grating and just plane boring to play  that I couldn't even bring myself to get to final level. The point where I stopped playing was when I burnt to death in a forest fire level, where slenderman appeared several times but I didn't notice because he blened in with the trees. In conclusion, just stick with the original Slender and all it's spinoff games if you found them scary, rather then throwing 10 bucks at this and getting basically the name thing with some pretty graphics.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Pretty solid game. Short but effective. The tension builds at a steady pace right up until the end. I loved how time would pass as you progressed, going from day time to night. Was a nice touch, as was the audio. Graphics are slightly dated, but still gorgeous. Of course it has its flaws. Maybe its intentional, but a save function would have been nice. The mine thing felt slightly out of place and a tiny bit forced (to me anyway). I ran into a couple bugs I found related to clicking letters and pausing while they were still open on the screen. Unpausing would cause the screen to go black and stay black. Happened most often at the very end of the prologue going into the next chapter. Not a huge deal, just annoying.Overall, its a pretty awesome game and I hope to see more from the devs.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Slender: The arrival is a fun yet terribly horrible experience. There arent many good horror games these days some examples of some good one are amnesia and outlast amongst others. This game comes at a close top. It has a good mix between tension and jump scares most are well placed and not repeating every 3 seconds. For a short game it gives you a lot of fun moments. It does have some drawbacks as the prive is too high for a game thats 2-3 hours worth of content and has no replay value. It also does come with its fair share of bugs nothing game breaking but you sometimes have to restart the game due to a missing object or getting stuck in a loading screen. I do recommend this game but not at full price pick it up at 50-60 percent off. 7/10 Great game.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												This review is updated after the free update.Slender: The Arrival in its first stages was a nice experience with good frights, a creative new story and new interesting characters, but it was too short and the history of the story was very faint and not much could be found. For exmple, we did not know much about Charlie Matheson, only rumours and suggestions from the easter egg, the poster and the few notes regarding him.However, this update isn't much, but for me it doesn't have to be. This update gives a Flashback to how it began, which was needed regarding the mystery above. Apart from that the update also gave the ability to replay the level found in the VCR, as well as a completely new place.This game now has a bit more to discover and play, and I really enjoyed it.11/15 - "Nice and short horror experience"

Posted: November 19, 2014
												Slender The Arrival is the sequel to The Eight Pages. This one is at least 10 times more scary. While some of it is SLIGHTLY repetetive, the game is Great! The graphics are amazing! There are 3 enemies in this game Including Slender Man, A hooded creature (Spoilers if I told you what it was) and Charlie. I was unsure about getting this at first but recently in October there was a HUGE updade and it added a new ending, extra levels, more music and bug fixes. So it is worth your time and £6.99 price tag (unless your from America or some other country that isn't the UK). The story is good and you are better off getting this than downloading The Eight Pages. After all this game contains a level once you complete the game called 'Genesis' which is the original Eight Pages game but Blue Isle Studios has edited it! Which is AWSOME.9/10 - Graet Story, Scary, Amazing Game!

Posted: June 17, 2015
												I was really impessed with this little horror treat. Beautiful graphics, great suspense building and effective jumpscares. Only downside, was very brief, could realistically finish it in 2 hours. Took me 3.6 because I'm a thorough explorer and I died a lot... first time I saw Slender I just ran right up to him to say hi... But other than that, it's much better than expected. And well worth it at the sale price of 3.99. I would place it somewhere between The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Outlast, as far as style and gameplay. If you like either one of those, and a good jumpscare, you'll like this one. The story seemed like a prologue, so hopefully it's just The Arrival and we'll see some fully fleshed out sequels. Definitely tracking this studio to see what they come up with next.BIG RECOMMENDATION!

Posted: November 30, 2014
Slender: The Arrival ReviewSequel to Slender: The Eight Pages. First person horror game.This game literally made me fall of my chair on multiple occasions. What an amazing sequel. I thought the original game was a clever concept for a horror game but this was just... pure terrifying. The fact that he's following you the whole time and that you can hear him rustling in the bushes, see him hiding behind the trees. It's like a long wait for him to kill you, because you know he's going to. Brilliant storyline, best atmosphere I've seen in a horror game for a while, terrible jumpscares! Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Let’s state right away that if you are not interested in Slender Man’s particular brand of horror this is not the game for you. Not much about the mythology is ever properly explained, and without prior knowledge of it you only get half of the experience out of the game. Sure, it’s a slow moving walking sim with some repetitive item hunts and cheap jump scares. But the real horror here comes from the atmosphere, you can never shake the feeling that whatever you do is empty gestures - the Slender Man is already planted in the mind of the protagonist and escape according to the mythos will be impossible. That underlying desperation and hopelessness is what makes the real horror here, not the jump scares. This is something that the game does very well in presenting with its empty and desolate yet beautiful settings, some fantastic lightning effects and of course the nail biting soundtrack. It’s not often you get a horror game where walking in a beautiful sunset feels like an unavoidable death sentence. There are some tedious parts though, especially the second chapter that is a remake of the original freeware title, due to the large size of the map and randomization of the item locations it can take forever to complete. There are only two of these big maps though and when you are past them some of the truly great chapters await.It’s an experience very much recommended for anyone crying from anxiety when watching the Marble Hornets series. Others may not be as forgiving to the uneven quality of the chapters or the cheap way the story is presented through scattered notes, but as a fan of the mythos it's one of the best walking sim horrors you can find.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Runs MUCH better after the patch, whoever patched this, thank you very much. The game is pretty great but it's criminally short with an unsatisfying ending. Personally it is pretty scary to me, I feel like anyone who wasn't scared at least once is a liar or is tough as nails. the only parts where I got stuck is the vhs part (because of the game not registering myself beating the first video) and parts where it is literally too dark to see what to do. the story itself ties in well with the first game but is also unique in its own right, slenderman is pretty spoopy especially when you're just starting to notice him in the background and he then disappears from sight. the first time he disappeared I was 100% sure he was behind me waiting for a jumpscare but strangely enough the game is pretty restrained for the first couple of minutes, it reels you in with the back-story and the mysterious disappearances. through the hidden level, it's implied that Charlie Matheson (the boy on the lost poster) is, more or less, the slenderman himself though this somewhat contradicts the optional level "memories." though this could actually imply through the ending of memories, not that he was killed by slenderman but somewhat acquired by the powers of the slenderman, it is also possible he becomes one of the proxies which could explain their ability to be seemingly everywhere and the fact that one of the proxies appears only after you pick up a train set and a rather familiar stuffed bear. That’s what makes this game interesting and fresh, not just the haunting, yet beautiful visuals, or the interesting story, or the homage’s to series like marble hornets and everyman hybrid, or even the "scary" internet slenderman, it's the amount of unanswered questions to be debated. i really hope for 10 or 15 dollars or whatever it is you give this game a spin, maybe if it's on sale and you're interested. This kind of game will simply keep you looking over your shoulders and the tree topped hills for weeks to come, looking for that mysterious, faceless man. Also as a side note, ♥♥♥♥ that cellar and give me back my twenty dollars spooperman.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game...I very much like this game. Slender: The Arrival is a basic survival horror game that relies heavily on jumpscares. But that is not a bad thing. I found myself being caught off guard at moments when I believed Slender nor his Proxies were going to show up. The way this game has impeccable and building atmosphere definitely adds to the stress and pressure the game puts out, also while increasing the creep factor. The way it has subtle story telling, and links itself in a major way to its predecessor, Slender: The Eight Pages, is amazing. I would definitely recommend this game to Slender fans and horror fanatics alike. 8.75/10

												Let’s state right away that if you are not interested in Slender Man’s particular brand of horror this is not the game for you. Not much about the mythology is ever properly explained, and without prior knowledge of it you only get half of the experience out of the game. Sure, it’s a slow moving walking sim with some repetitive item hunts and cheap jump scares. But the real horror here comes from the atmosphere, you can never shake the feeling that whatever you do is empty gestures - the Slender Man is already planted in the mind of the protagonist and escape according to the mythos will be impossible. That underlying desperation and hopelessness is what makes the real horror here, not the jump scares. This is something that the game does very well in presenting with its empty and desolate yet beautiful settings, some fantastic lightning effects and of course the nail biting soundtrack. It’s not often you get a horror game where walking in a beautiful sunset feels like an unavoidable death sentence. There are some tedious parts though, especially the second chapter that is a remake of the original freeware title, due to the large size of the map and randomization of the item locations it can take forever to complete. There are only two of these big maps though and when you are past them some of the truly great chapters await.It’s an experience very much recommended for anyone crying from anxiety when watching the Marble Hornets series. Others may not be as forgiving to the uneven quality of the chapters or the cheap way the story is presented through scattered notes, but as a fan of the mythos it's one of the best walking sim horrors you can find.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Runs MUCH better after the patch, whoever patched this, thank you very much. The game is pretty great but it's criminally short with an unsatisfying ending. Personally it is pretty scary to me, I feel like anyone who wasn't scared at least once is a liar or is tough as nails. the only parts where I got stuck is the vhs part (because of the game not registering myself beating the first video) and parts where it is literally too dark to see what to do. the story itself ties in well with the first game but is also unique in its own right, slenderman is pretty spoopy especially when you're just starting to notice him in the background and he then disappears from sight. the first time he disappeared I was 100% sure he was behind me waiting for a jumpscare but strangely enough the game is pretty restrained for the first couple of minutes, it reels you in with the back-story and the mysterious disappearances. through the hidden level, it's implied that Charlie Matheson (the boy on the lost poster) is, more or less, the slenderman himself though this somewhat contradicts the optional level "memories." though this could actually imply through the ending of memories, not that he was killed by slenderman but somewhat acquired by the powers of the slenderman, it is also possible he becomes one of the proxies which could explain their ability to be seemingly everywhere and the fact that one of the proxies appears only after you pick up a train set and a rather familiar stuffed bear. That’s what makes this game interesting and fresh, not just the haunting, yet beautiful visuals, or the interesting story, or the homage’s to series like marble hornets and everyman hybrid, or even the "scary" internet slenderman, it's the amount of unanswered questions to be debated. i really hope for 10 or 15 dollars or whatever it is you give this game a spin, maybe if it's on sale and you're interested. This kind of game will simply keep you looking over your shoulders and the tree topped hills for weeks to come, looking for that mysterious, faceless man. Also as a side note, ♥♥♥♥ that cellar and give me back my twenty dollars spooperman.

												I'd start by saying I used to be a huge fan of everything slenderman, I triend making my own slender game, I played this game like 5 times. But it took me until now to realize that this game shouldn't still be $10. Sure it's not much but the game overall is short. I beat it in one sitting and although the scares are pretty good you shouldn't expect a ton of content. But on the brightside the story is pretty good and you'll find more story if you pay attention to detail. One annoying thing is that although the game doesn't look... great. And there isn't much other stuff going on the game can still be a bit taxing on slightly older hardware. I currently have an HP Pavilion G6 which isn't a bad laptop but it is from about 2013 or so and because the Unity 3D engine isn't greatly optimized the game didn't run very amazing. Although I have said all of these negative things about the game I'd still go ahead and reccomend getting it but only if it is on sale. I don't believe it should still be $10.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												NOTE: I had to set some custom launch options to et the lighting to work AT ALL in this game, so if you're looking or a game to quickly install and work flawlessly right away, you should wait until these errors are resolved by the devs. This game does a good job at reviving The Slenderman as a creepy and mysterious being, unlike the Slenderman we're bombarded with on all corners of the internet, generally in the form of poorly written crepypastas or a pony fan-fictions. This game takes the basic gameplay mechanic from the original Slender: The Eight Pages and gives it some beautiful scenery, smooth graphics, and new environments and scenarios to make it a fresh, (and eery) new experience. The story is very cut and dry, but the lack of backstory creates a feeling of unknowing, which adds to the uneasy and creepy atmosphere. When I bought this I was expecting a slightly modified version of Slender: The Eight Pages, quite honestly, but when the screen turned bright and I was suddenly in the middle of a beautiful forest at dawn, I was slightly surprised. I was even more suprised as I suddenly realized it was dark, as I walked deeper into the forest with no flashlight. The atmoshphere this game creates right off the bat is amazing, and left me wanting to play more. I would definitely reccomend this game despite its bugs.

												47 MINUTES. I've played it twice so far. I am literally shaking writing this."Its only a computer game - how old are you ffs - keep going" - camera starts shaking - i'm deep in the woods running from light source to light source. Picking up scrawled notes that are getting a bit more disturbed each time.Camera shaking - noises everywhere - FOOTSTEPS! - its gone, i think, i hope....ooOOooo another note i'll just run over - Aaagh camera going mental - not really sure if thats a bad thing, probably i suppose.AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGH!!! WTF is that ?? I JUMP FROM MY KEYBOARD.I am frozen. 5 seconds went by - i grab the mouse and turn back to where that faceless figure stood. gone. I'm shaking - this is MENTAL.I run around the corner and crouch. looking frantically around me - 2 box containers behind me. i work my way from right to left - oh♥♥♥♥♥♥is that a hand ? no no no no no no no no no no no - i'm dead.47 minutes so far.2 games have made me scream and this is one of them. i will play more - just not now - i cant.HIGHLY recommend this gem.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Slender: The Arrival (S:TA) is a game with a history that maybe well-known to web enthusiasts. The story of Slender, or Slender Man to be precise, was originally an internet phenomenon that had people grasping for the story of this illusive Slender Man that has been "found" in writings, pictures, and videos. People have collectively created or contributed to a character of horror through the internet by way of social networks, YouTube and word-of-mouth. S:TA is the next medium in the mythos of Slender Man as it allows you to explore a world where Slender Man exists. You're objective is to uncover the story, piece it together and above all, survive! This game is very atmosphere and has a great level of detail for an Indie game so dive in and let yourself be taken by Slender. It should be noted that the original game, Slender: The Eight Pages, is presented as a bonus campaign called, "Genesis."

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												It is a wonderful horror game. Based on Slender: eight pages, this game enhances everything include visual presentation, sound effect, special effect...etc. If you like eight pages, don't miss this one.Attention: This game adopts JUMP SCARE technique heavily, if you can't accept, then skip this one. Players in this game have to achieve certain goal, collect eight pages for example, in dark environment, and the freaking Slender Man will WARPS around to hunt you. When you wander in dark forest, you don't know when it will appear, all you can do is complete the goal as fast as possible and pray, you will be nervous all the time. When you see it, the screen will distort with freaking sound, a creepy man with no face, unusually slender body that definitely not a human, stand still in darkness, it will freak you out, and you can't look at it too longer or stand still too, run for your life, otherwise it will capture you. The tension, the uncertainty, the pressure to complete goal under creepy atmosphere, all of these make terrifying experiences outstanding, it works perfectly to scare people.The more you approaching the goal, Slender Man will warps more close to you and more frequent, you will be capture easily one step before achieving the goal, you may retry many times to walkthrough a episode, it somewhat difficult and it's on purpose, "How long you can last" is the core intention for this game, but sometime it may cause frustration, repetitive gameplay due to diffculty may ruin your terrifying experience, I suggest play it on easy if you are casual player or want to keep terrifying experience FRESHLY.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Good to see the game is fully optimized in the 2.0 update.  This is a great follow up to the 8 pages with updated graphics and atmosphere.  Initially the game seemed to aim at a more photorealistic approach but with bugs and poor optimization.  Along followed updates to the game with better optimization but with sacrifices to the games photorealism and effects.  Hopefully another follow-up to the game will hit that mark of photorealism.  Overall the game is still great and the developers deserve recognition for putting the effort into keeping the game updated and fully supported for optimization on 3 platforms now (not many small development teams do this).

												This game is a great game for anybody that is into the legend "Slender Man" and i highly reccomend it to the average horror lets player. I think that Slender: The Arrival, was a huge step forward into the horror game franchise. If you have not tried Slender The Arrival i reccomend you do asap. If your steam wallet is looking empty, there are times when you can get Slender The Arrival on sale around most of the holidays. This game is a great game for anybody that liked Slender: The Eight Pages. If you dont have the minimum system requirements and own any console like Wii u, Xbox 360, Playstation 3 then you are able to buy the game later this year. Also, if you own the oculus rift it has a setting where you are able to play using the Oculus Rift. All you have to do is type this in the console: toggle VR, when you type that then you will enable virtual reality/ Oculus Rift. This game comes out with updates that add on to the original game so that you always get a new experience. The graphics in Slender The Arrival are phenominal for a horror game too. Again if you haven't tried Slender The Arrival, i would reccoomend that you do so now.                                             Game Score: 9.8 out of 10

												9.99 is a bit much, but if you're a fan of Slender it will probably be worth it. The game is certainly creepy. It's not as elegant as, say, Amnesia, but it still has its moments.There's just something about a non-moving, faceless monster that almost looks human that just terrifies me to my core. The music and sound are perfect and the story is cool to figure out. I don't know if it's because I bought it before it was on Steam, but you can use the console with ~ to access cheats. You won't get achievements, but hey, it's available if you want to explore the game's design.

Posted: January 6, 2014
BUY IT! (If you have the braveness and 8,99€ left!)In "Slender: The Arrival" you play as Lauren, a friend of Kate, who disappeared in one night.You, as a good friend, try to find her - but you notice that you be followed...by Slender.There is one way to kill him - but you don't know how.!SPOILER ALERT! Another friend, called "CR" trys also to find Kate and he knows how to end this!Slender: The Arrival - you are special, but not that special. You have about 3 scary things - Slender. Playtime. Soundtrack.++ It's Slender++ It has finally a kind of a (good) story+ the soundtrack is good and creepy+ the control isn't that good, but not too bad+ you can find notes, letters (which are important - to understand)+ the graphic is really nice+ you can play 6 levels with a nice atmosphere+ EXTRA: If you play with a friend => much more fun!+ Easy achievements (in my opinion)- playtime of about 1 hour (if you run through the sh.it) which isn't worth 8,99€- Hardcore modus isn't so extremly hard...made it in 3 attempts- story is hard to understand...in the first or second run- no more fun to go into the forest... THANK YOU!- not really a big replayability factor- "Shift+W"-buttons are dead- don't use the soundtrack as alarm clock.- 6 levels with Slender...it hears nice, but you will get bored fast (if you play more than 3 times the whole game)"Slender: The Arrival" you deserve 6/10!

												7.7/10 - One Of The Scariest Games You Can Play! Top Horror Contender!This game is pretty impressive; it uses elements I really don't like such as dark areas to explore and the use of flashlight. These are both usually recipes for failure but this game executes these features really well. It's still cumbersome to navigate the maps and find the clues though, so if you are easily frustrated with that like me; be prepared.The controls and graphics are definitely the best part; the maps are brilliant in color and lighting which really sets the mood and creates a fear factor.I'd pay $10; usually on sale for $2 which is a steal! Accidently ReviewedWas this review helpful or maybe even not helpful? Either way join this group for more. Free Keys and Reviews weekly!
 Steam Group: AccidentlyReviewed

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												I must admit, this game looks and controls very, very nicely. However, the gameplay reuses the original Slender's "Collect all the pages" in levels far too many times, the story feels rather shallow (they introduce several characters that you never meet, all of which who hunt for and are then hunted for the fabled Slenderman- and you're just another one of them), the graphics- although they look nice- look to have all been taken from various free asset packs I have seen before, and... who was that guy in the hoodie who chased and attacked me?Overall, the game CAN be fun, but all-in-all, it's rather bland and repetitive. This is one of the few games where I'd reccomend you watch someone else online play (without commentary is usually best)- you'll probably get the same experience either way.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Slender the arrival is a horrible game. Almost everything in this game pisses me off to no end, and made me angry that I wasted 10 bucks on this awful "horror" game.THE GOODThere are a few good things about this game. One is the graphics. The graphics, while unimpressive in the lower settings, looks GREAT in the higher settings. The best parts of the game were walking around in the lit areas, exploring the forest at your own pase, as slender does not appear in these sections. It is a shame that they are very short. The last thing I like is the is the very first level in kate's house. You start out in the sunset, walking to an abandoned house as the sun slowly goes down. Once you get in the house, it's pitch black. You then find a flashlight, and can explore the house as much as you like. One of the rooms is locked and once opened, causes a great scare involving the slender man watching you explore the room outside from the window. Its a very creepy opening and makes a great first impression. Shame the other levels were not like this...THE BADHere's the fun part. Lets start out with it the biggest flaw that will ruin every horror game. IT IS NOT SCARY AT ALL.all the game consists of are cheap, and I mean CHEAP jumps scares that did not startle me at all. Now let me explain something: Jump scares can be well made. If the game uses the features and mechanics found in the game to make the jump scare, it can be done extremely well. Great examples are: Resident Evil 1-4, Outlast, and SCP containment breach. This game however, does not do that and goes for the cheap jump scares found in most♥♥♥♥♥♥horror movies like Insidious and the new Paranormal Activity movies. Another thing I hate is the gameplay.  I could explain it to you but ill just summarize the games objectives for you. In the second level, guess what you have to do? Get 8 pages. In the third level, guess what you have to do? Turn on 6 generators in a large map. In the fourth level, guess what's next? YOU HAVE TO CLOSE 8 DOORS AND WINDOWS!!! Its just the same task over and over and got boring very quick. now lets talk about difficulty. This game is hard. But not the good kind of hard that tests your skills or anything, Im talking about INSANELY cheap deaths. There are times were a character who is not slender man (whom I cannot say the name of as that would be spoilers) chases after you and jumps on you, leaving you limping for a few seconds. But sometimes out of the blue, SHE WILL KILL YOU WHEN SHE JUMPS ON YOU! There's nothing that tells you "Hey, your going to die if you get attacked again" and  also, you do not have a certain amount of times you can be attacked, believe me, I tested it. The same applys for the slenderman himself. Sometimes he will appear and give you a chance to escape, or sometimes he will say "♥♥♥♥ it" and insta-kill you. This is extremely frustrating in the final level where he appears right in front of you, making you either barley come out alive, or escape, but to then be insta-killed by his damn tentacles. Finally, the game is very short. wanna know EXACTLY how long it took me to beat this game? 58 MINUTES. Sure, my recorded hours say 2, but that is only because I spent a hour testing the games settings to see which would run best on my laptop. While I was happy as this experience was over very fast, its bad for the people who somehow enjoy it, as there game will be over in a flash.THE VERDICTThis game is honestly, the worst horror game I have ever played. Don't even buy it on sale, unless you somehow get it for free, or get it gifted from a friend,it is not worth a penny. 2.5/10 AVOID AT ALL COST!For more reviews, go to our true reviewers group:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/truereviewI apologize for most of the poor gramar found in this review.Also, lets face it, the only reason this game is popular is becuase that retard Pewdiepie lets plays the slender games 24/7.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												A terrifyingly unfrightful game which has you, a silent protagonist, look for his friend "Kate", investigate an area while picking up 8 pieces of paper while you're stalked by a mentally challenged individual who wears a sock on his head and a suit. Lots of static for the faint of heart, plenty of eerie low rumbling sounds in dark areas and a generic world that forces you, the player, to "immerse" yourself into is something that the game offers. If one were to look for a decent horror title which does not base it's horror of a drearily paced, monotonous environment flicking switches and travelling as if the main character has a third of his thighs removed thus causing a wobbly running effect then it would be better to go back to Resident Evil. Or Evil Within. Or Amnesia or Penumbra! Those are nice titles.TL;DR avoid if you find Five Nights at Freddy's boring, purchase if you are easily frightened by lame indie titles.Now, give me those downvotes now you rabid fans.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												A bone chilling game to the end. Gamers will experience what true psychological horror is like when they play this game. The game itself will not let you keep thinking about it, it's the origins that will letyou think about it. Slenderman is a very popular mythos spread across the web, especially on some well-known forums, such as Creepypasta and many others. This game, however, completes it by making it a chilling experience to finally complete the Slender sage. What's more is that the slender saga is not even completed yet. They say there's about to be the sequel to this soon. Anyway, they added more content to the levels, in order to make the experience even more epic. I really recommend this game to many people, especially horror fans. This game may be of the same horror class as Outlast; a lot of jumpscares, but from a totally diffrent perspective.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												If you're looking for a fruitful, new, graphically amazing version of Slender, then this is for you.I enjoyed it immensely. I was actually able to follow the story even with being distracted by my stream since I streamed the whole 4.2 hours I currently have on it.I was able to jump right into it and understand it and enjoy it, so that's a plus for a simple minded person like me. xDRatings:Gameplay: 4/5 (I would have to say 4/5 because it was an amazing story but short lived game! I really hope that they make more since it is titled "The Arrival", but who knows! Still great gameplay though!)Graphics: 4/5 (Putting this game on top quality makes it beautiful, sometimes at night with the flashlight things look a bit funky but not enough to affect the score greatly. Slender and Charlie definitely had me running away with how good they looked.)Storyline: 5/5 (I personally really enjoyed the story and I was able to keep up with it. It immersed you in every part of the story to so you could either relive it or create it. For such a short timed game, it was definitely a good story keeping in mind it incorporates Slender.)Sp00ki level: 5/5 (I'm easily scared but I would still even give it a 5/5 because Charlie is VERY spooki when you're trying to do stuff and he comes and screams in your face. Slender is a little unfair and unkind at some points, he wouldn't even square up and fight me... BUT oh well. All the characters are definitely spooky and will rustle your jimmies.)

												Not too bad of a game. The game is actually quite scary, mostly jump scares but the atmosphere is really good too. The sound can be set to surround by many of the ambient sounds like the wind dont come from the rear channels, and so the surround sound is a bit lousy. The graphics are surprising realisitic. The atmosphere of the game is what makes it really good and the lurking enemies can be quite a challenge. i had to set it to easy to make it through getting the eight pages. Finished the game in one day, but it wasnt bad for a low priced game. Not much replayability but good once through. The story is interesting enough.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												A fantastic remake of the original Slender game. The graphics and sounds have been remade and Slenderman has never looked better. The maps are big, well detailed and beautiful.But the game has lost some of the original charm that made it so awesome. The scariest thing about the original Slender game was its simplicity. Find 8 pages, that is it. Slenderman was truly frightning and I often crapped my pants when he appeared. The graphics are beautiful, but the downside is that you are not as frightened. You can easily break Slendy. He will rarely ever appear in front of you. All you need to do is walk straight and only look back a couple of times. I spent 40 minutes walking around the 8 pages level searching for the last page, with Slendy behind me. Not once did I feel scared and when he appeared in front, i just turned around and said nope.avi.Granted, the abandoned mine was compensation. That was a truly horrific experience. Worthy remake of the original, with beautiful visuals and sound, but a part of its original charm is gone.

content:

												Slender: The Arrival is truly a jump scare master piece, from grapics to gameplay, It has it all. Seeing how a 7-16 feet tall (said to be actuly estimated hight) Suit wearing blank white face man is truly creppy, disturbing and frightening most of the time. Slender man phisicly is showing what he can and will do you, like chaseing you around a park looking for eight pages, sending in   his PROXY helper who is really your childhood friend, To even hunting you down endlessly in a forest fire. Even he has special moving animations spicifcly triggerd when you get more objectives compleated, like a huntching over animation or A very freakishly tentacle(s) appearingout of his back when almost caught. Not jumpscarey enough? Play on HARDCORE as he will NEVER let you run away from is grasp......I truly recomend this game to any Slender fans or people who like to play just for jumpscares. 4.5/5......9/10. Just perfect.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Two years after this game was released, it's still an incredible, chilling experience.Slender: The Arrival is THE Slender game; a simple story with a backstory that leaves you with more questions than answers... but that's what makes the mystery all the more enticing. BEAUTIFUL graphics with such simple details. You view the world through a video camera in a 'Blair Witch Project' atmosphere.The environments are stunning during the day; a beautiful forest in what looks like upstate California with fall leaves, sunlight filtering through the branches and lensflares on your camera. But then at night, the beauty is tarnished as you're alone and hunted in an ebony black wasteland of wood, isolated and with nothing but a flashlight to protect you.Slender isn't the ONLY one after you in this game either...A bit of a scavenger-hunt game with find-it tasks, but it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Slenderman approves!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												I don't scare easily at all. Horror movies make me laugh most of the time. The last time I can remember being terrified was when I watched Poltergeist as a kid--my brother had clowns on his side of the room. Well...screw you, Slender! This game scared the♥♥♥♥♥♥outta me (and my 14 year-old son who was watching). Played for about 15 minutes and had to stop to let my nerves calm down.I'm only on the second "level/chapter/whatever", and it's just brilliant. Best scares I've had in a game ever (Silent Hill previously held such honor).I don't know what the original version was like, but this updated offering is gorgeous. The bloom effects and lighting are quite nice. I will say that the character model shadows are pretty pixelated, and the ground seems very low-res, but otherwise it's a terrific looking game.Seems like there is controller support, but for some reason mine wouldn't work (Xbox 360 controller for Windows). Not a huge deal, but could be a deal-breaker for folks that only play controller-supported games on their own makeshift "Steam Machines" (like my brother).Excellent game, with superb atmosphere, lighting, sound, and CREEPINESS! If you're looking to be scared, then this will do the trick.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												A fantastic remake of the original Slender game. The graphics and sounds have been remade and Slenderman has never looked better. The maps are big, well detailed and beautiful.But the game has lost some of the original charm that made it so awesome. The scariest thing about the original Slender game was its simplicity. Find 8 pages, that is it. Slenderman was truly frightning and I often crapped my pants when he appeared. The graphics are beautiful, but the downside is that you are not as frightened. You can easily break Slendy. He will rarely ever appear in front of you. All you need to do is walk straight and only look back a couple of times. I spent 40 minutes walking around the 8 pages level searching for the last page, with Slendy behind me. Not once did I feel scared and when he appeared in front, i just turned around and said nope.avi.Granted, the abandoned mine was compensation. That was a truly horrific experience. Worthy remake of the original, with beautiful visuals and sound, but a part of its original charm is gone.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Slender: The Arrival could have been something great. With a much larger dev team than the original Slender: The Eight Pages, and a story written by the creators of the wonderful Marble Hornets YouTube series, you'd think it would be pretty awesome. But unfortunately, while the graphics may be very beautiful, and while the atmosphere may at first feel very foreboding and creepy, the actual scares aren't very, well, scary. The Slender Man isn't a threat, he's an annoyance. To overcome him, you simply have to look away from him, and keep your distance. As long as you adhere to those two rules, there is NO WAY you can fail. And The Chaser isn't any better. All you have to do is simply shine your flashlight at The Chaser repeatedly to stun her, and then run away. These two characters aren't enemies, they're pests. The only things standing between you and your goal in a horror game are the antagonists. The point of a horror game is to be scary. When you can avoid your antagonists so easily, it makes the game not scary. And when your horror game isn't scary, that mean's you have completely failed. Not only are the scares lackluster, but so is the gameplay and story. The missions consist of finding eight items or activating six generators while avoiding the Slender Man or Chaser (which, like I said before, isn't very difficult), or simply walking from point A to point B. The objectives are very repetetive, and combined with the lack of tension aside from a few cheap jump scares, the missions are boring and not very fun. Slender's story fails as well because everything feels very pointless. Why is your character trying to find eight pages? Why doesn't she just turn around and leave? Why are we supposed to believe that a radio tower is a safe place aside from the fact that the game just tells us that it's safe? All of these questions (and more) are never answered. The writers of the story (Troy Wagner, Tim Sutton, and Joseph Delage) said that the development team warped and manipulated their original story which, if true, might explain the poor narrative quality. Combine the lack of scares, shallow story, repetetive gameplay with the short time it takes to complete the game (45 minutes-1 hour), and you have one huge letdown of a game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
My In-depth ReviewI played the Unity Prototype when it was first release. Comparing it to this is like comparing how a Bike to a car. So there is some hardcore difference! it is exciting that the original developer got to bring this title to reality & sell it on steam.I was little bit disappointed with the result, but kind of was not expecting much.... so here is my review. enjoy Visuals  Were great, the outdoors had a very beautiful feel/look.  but Indoor environments the textures were extremely buggy. With low res images and lack of detail in geometry. The problem with first person games is that you are going to see the environments up close… technically meaning that attention to detail is important.But with Slender: The Arrival it heavily lacked the amount of polish and overall looked a slighty improved version of the prototype. (Talking about Gameplay/feel, not the features they added ontop)GameplayAt its core, it has extremely simple easy to follow gameplay. There are at times when you wish there was alittle more. But overall it pulls it off. Replay ability? Not really that much, the game is really empty at its core once you have completed it. Nothing really new you could gain by playing it again. The only thing is if you wanted to get all the achivements. But even that is a feels like a grind/chore when you have nothing new to keep your interest. Final thoughtsThe game is a fantastic achievement, however I don't really think i can justify it as a finished game. Gameplay and mechanics... Yes that is finished. But lacking a good solid art direction in the indoor sections hinders my decision on it been finished. (ie: less repeating assets, less pixelated textures, more detail in the Architecture structure of the buildings. (for example in the mine). as there really was no story to tell in that environement that you could see. It was dull uninteresting environement with typical random decal textures of Graffiti  sprayed everywhere. and repeating assets, no evidence  what so ever of who lived/worked here before. it seemed the developer simply duplicated assets around the level and rotating them around a bit. without thought of level design from the players perspective.If you do end up getting this game. I guarantee you will get a fright out of it during some point of gameplay however you will eventually see the small holes that shine through that strip it the title of a ‘AMAZING game’ but rather calling it a good game.Thank you.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Slender: The Arrival could have been something great. With a much larger dev team than the original Slender: The Eight Pages, and a story written by the creators of the wonderful Marble Hornets YouTube series, you'd think it would be pretty awesome. But unfortunately, while the graphics may be very beautiful, and while the atmosphere may at first feel very foreboding and creepy, the actual scares aren't very, well, scary. The Slender Man isn't a threat, he's an annoyance. To overcome him, you simply have to look away from him, and keep your distance. As long as you adhere to those two rules, there is NO WAY you can fail. And The Chaser isn't any better. All you have to do is simply shine your flashlight at The Chaser repeatedly to stun her, and then run away. These two characters aren't enemies, they're pests. The only things standing between you and your goal in a horror game are the antagonists. The point of a horror game is to be scary. When you can avoid your antagonists so easily, it makes the game not scary. And when your horror game isn't scary, that mean's you have completely failed. Not only are the scares lackluster, but so is the gameplay and story. The missions consist of finding eight items or activating six generators while avoiding the Slender Man or Chaser (which, like I said before, isn't very difficult), or simply walking from point A to point B. The objectives are very repetetive, and combined with the lack of tension aside from a few cheap jump scares, the missions are boring and not very fun. Slender's story fails as well because everything feels very pointless. Why is your character trying to find eight pages? Why doesn't she just turn around and leave? Why are we supposed to believe that a radio tower is a safe place aside from the fact that the game just tells us that it's safe? All of these questions (and more) are never answered. The writers of the story (Troy Wagner, Tim Sutton, and Joseph Delage) said that the development team warped and manipulated their original story which, if true, might explain the poor narrative quality. Combine the lack of scares, shallow story, repetetive gameplay with the short time it takes to complete the game (45 minutes-1 hour), and you have one huge letdown of a game.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												When I first came across this game, I was extremely excited. Finally, a Slenderman game with an actual story other then some random chick gathering pages. Slenderman himself looks amazing in this game, (The only complaint I have is that the tendrils are lacking in their appearence.) and also, he's not the only one you deal with. The effects of coming into contact with the Slenderman are intense, much so that if you're not even expecting it, could rip you out of your seat instantly. You CAN get trapped. Slenderman does more then just teleport. Though, I do give this game a definite thumbs up, there is room for improvement. Falling through floors, Slenderman freezing in place and ruining cutscenes... there's some mishaps. But over all, definitely give this game a try. Beware, Slenderman can instantly kill you in this one; But isn't that realistic? ;)

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Two years after this game was released, it's still an incredible, chilling experience.Slender: The Arrival is THE Slender game; a simple story with a backstory that leaves you with more questions than answers... but that's what makes the mystery all the more enticing. BEAUTIFUL graphics with such simple details. You view the world through a video camera in a 'Blair Witch Project' atmosphere.The environments are stunning during the day; a beautiful forest in what looks like upstate California with fall leaves, sunlight filtering through the branches and lensflares on your camera. But then at night, the beauty is tarnished as you're alone and hunted in an ebony black wasteland of wood, isolated and with nothing but a flashlight to protect you.Slender isn't the ONLY one after you in this game either...A bit of a scavenger-hunt game with find-it tasks, but it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Slenderman approves!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												To be completely honest, I really, really dislike the note collecting mechanic that was populerized with these games. But Slender was innovative and frightening for its time and so this remake at least deserves a fair shake in the wake of the many knockoffs on the market since. As far as Slenderman games go, this one stands a head above. The graphics are fantastic, the sounds and music very atmospheric. The story branches across several different points of view that develop as you play through the experiences of a number of people that have been hunted by Slenderman and have come together over time. While the note collecting (and now generator-activating) shtick is still there, it's not the only mechanic present, which is a refreshing change. While I'm not sure it's worth the full price, picking it up on sale isn't a bad deal.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												The game starts of as a decent title, but as soon as you figure out how simple and nonsensical the gameplay mechanics are everything seems just too shallow. It has a few good scares and the whole concept of a supernatural entity stalking you is very interesting, however, game lacks depth. There are also some irritating difficulty spikes and the game is simply unfair in some instances. Few levels are memorable and to the game credit creepy as hell, unfortunately tyhe game seems a little bit too short and extra content is nowhere to be seen so far.Overall Slender the Arrival is a mediocre game, which relies too much on oversimplified game mechanics combined with creepy atmosphere. On the plus side music is great, and ambient sounds are perfect at creating tension, however, there are better games fo play so save your money or wait for extra content to be added or a discount price.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Slender: The Arrival is a short game where the player takes control of Lauren who is searching for her friend, Kate, in the middle of the forest controlled by the omnipresent Slender Man. With players viewing the action through Lauren's video camera, the game is at first deeply atmospheric but flaws that hinder the experience soon become apparent.The majority of Slender: The Arrival involves the player walking through dark, open environments where the Slender Man can appear from anywhere. On a first playthrough, Slender: The Arrival is very tense, with each step forward making the player feel uneasy. The overall atmosphere is bleak with finely presented environments, eerie music and collectible notes helping construct an unsettling experience. Players familiar with Slender Man lore will undoubtedly find the experience more unnerving than those who are not. Despite the rich atmosphere and tangible tension, Slender: The Arrival turns into a trivial, almost dull game once the Slender Man actually appears. The first time a player observes the Slender Man, their inital response is most likely one of fright. However, each time the Slender Man appears on screen, the frightning effect is diminished. Players will soon realise that the game consists of a foe that can teleport around the environment to provide cheap jump scares and little more. It soon becomes tedious and if one were to turn around and see the Slender Man merely floating toward them as if it were on a wire, it all becomes easily managable.Slender: The Arrival is good during the first hour but it soon becomes a tedious collection of jump scares which fail to fright and interactions with a folkloreish entity that strips away all creditable mystery or menace. Even harder difficulty settings fail to improve the frights in a lacklustre horror experience.

												Slender is a fairly simple game; it is not complex whatsoever.You can customize your settings such as keybinds and graphics, but be warned, you cannot change your keybinds inside the game. I have no game controllers - however all my character did for two days straight was spin in aimless circles and was unmovable. If you want some mediocre horror; this is for you. The creepy sounds might make you itch the back of your neck while trying to figure out what it was, but overall, it's really just a solid->gradient slenderman.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Slender: The Arrival was developed by Blue Isle Studios in collaboration with Mark J Hadley, the developer of the original Slender the Eight Pages in 2012. The Arrival is an excellent psychological and atmospheric, story driven horror game in which the player takes on the role of Lauren, who is investigating the disappearance of her friend. As well as facing new enemies such as Slender Man's Proxy, the player can immerse themselves in an all-new, unique and innovative storyline. Players are introduced to a 'scrapbook' feature in which they can view the collectibles that they are able to find throughout the game. The Arrival is a truly interactive and immersive experience. Players will also be rewarded with longer gameplay, stunning visuals and a soundtrack equally as beautiful as it is terrifying and tense. Fans of the original Slender game are presented with a remake of The Eight Pages. Chapter 9 'Genesis' contains all the original landmarks and page locations from the 2012 game, the only difference is that of much improved graphics and lighting for a greater gameplay experience. I recommend this game to all fans of horror whether they be new or familiar with the genre. A must have; 10/10[NOTE: CHAPTER 9 'GENESIS' IS NOT PART OF THE 'SLENDER THE ARRIVAL' STORY LINE, IT IS JUST A REMAKE OF 'THE EIGHT PAGES' FOR FANS TO ENJOY!]

You need to turn on the things with out the little kid trying to brake your legs.But I won't ruin the rest of the game or the ending for you. But there is much more to this game then meets the eye. If you're into scary games and trying to figure out the storyline of a game at the same time. Then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Slender: The Arrival is good...for an indie game.It's probably the best Slenderman game to come out of the hoard of other games that tried to capitalize on the success of the original, but that's not saying much.Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed Slenderman: The Eight Pages, and I even liked the idea of having Slenderman's aggression dependent on the amount of pages you'd collected. It was a fresh idea, but it wasn't exactly compelling or fleshed-out enough to warrant spending any more than 30 minutes to an hour with it.Slender: The Arrival aims to lenghten, and provide greater context to the original idea, but it hardly manages to do either successfully.The story is presented to the player through signs and notes that are scattered around each environment in the game, and its your job to collect them and determine what happened in Slenderman Land. Who (or what) is Slenderman? What happened to the family who lived there? Who are they, and why is Slenderman targeting them? The game definitely raises more questions than it answers, so be prepared for dissapointment if you were expecting a decent payoff. Even if you do manage to piece it together, the story is textbook horror, and it doesn't offer any significant surprises or revelations.The game is dissapointingly short as well, clocking in at 2 hours or less on normal difficulty, depending on how often you need to retry the difficult sections of the game. If you go into to Slenderman: The Arrival with low expectations, you might find it enjoyable. The visuals look nice, and the audio design is suitably creepy when it needs to be. In all honesty, it's impressive when you consider that this is Blue Isle Stuidio's first game, but at the end of the day though, Slenderman: The Arrival is undone by its cryptic storytelling and ridiculously short length. I'd only recommend that you pick it up when it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Slender the Arrival does it's best to give you a creepy experience but it just keeps falling flat. It is a very nonintuitive game. It's standard first person shooter controls (without the shooter) and places you in the creepy woods of a park. One of its main shortcomings is that it lacks the ability to deliver the story properly. We are supposed to make assumptions about everything. Assumptions that are probably wrong. I kept finding clues about a person and assumed that person might be me. Then it took reading some backstory in a walkthru to discover that I was a completely different person baguely mentioned in one of the notes. The first few times I played it I was throughly creeped out and some of the presentation helped with that. It uses a method of "steady-cam" view that looks like you are filming this which can also be viewed that you are someone else watching this person's footage (a la Blair Witch Project, CLoverfield, or Paranormal Activity). What you find does heighten the tension and when odd things are seen it really creeps you out. But then it feels like a grind. Where am I supposed to go next you ask. Oh over there. Wait I think I've found everything. Do I go back? Where to next? There is a decisivve lack of direction and instruction. It gave me a goal but the goal was so vague that I didn't know whether I was finished nor did I know if I was finding the right things. I wandered around doing nothing SLOWLY for a half hour and then quit the game. Why? HEre is the biggeswt problem. There is no save feature. It saves once you finish "THE CHAPTER". I was stuck in the "prologue" for days. Every time I tried it I had to start from the beginning. So by the 15th time I tried finding all the clues or whatever I was not afraid of the woods nor the creepy things. So far all I've seen are creepy things but none of them are harmful things. Don't get me wrong. This game has figured out that in horror you can't just in-your-face all the horror like Dead Space or Doom 3 etc. But it has to be subtle. But it hasn't fuguyred out pacing, story, furthering the adventure. It also relies a lot on camera glitches and sound effects and music. THose things are very important in horror. But in this case I am never sure if these elements actually appear in the game world or just in the game "providing atmosphere" like I'm being followed around by a 40s radio SFX guy banging pots together and breathing heavily. It reminds me of the scares in the movie The Ring where Ehren Krueger hit us over the head with loud noises and in your face weird cut in pictures to scare us and when you got to the end all you could say was "Huh?"I would be interested if this studio tried it again with horror as this was an improvement over its predecessor but it still isn't there. The controls and gameplay are still lacking. Your RUNNING mode isn't much faster than your WALKING mode. You can neither jump nor go in water so you feel like a child in one of those wheelie guides. The story needs a bit of polish. There needs to be a definite indication who I am and what I'm doing and how far I've gotten with it. Because leaving it up to my imagination is unacceptable in a game. How am _I_ supposed to know when I am done with a chapter if I don't know what I'm supposed to be looking for, etc.This will keep you entertained for a couple playthroughs until you give up and look through the readthroughs. (which don't really help as the items keep moving around) You want to get really scared, go for Five Nights at Freddy's.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Slender: The Eight Pages, is the scariest game I have ever played. The gameplay is simple, deiliberately repetitive, and frightening. Slender: The Arrival, is a very scary game - but not as scary. That is how to describe Slender: The Arrival in a nutshell for fans of the original game. For those unfamiliar with the horror masterpiece that is Slender: The Eight Pages, I will explain. Slender: The Eight Pages, drops you into the middle of the woods, in a disturbingly eerie nighttime filled with fog, bushes, and worst of all: undescribable darkness. Your goal is to look for 8 pages. As you collect each page however, you find that you are slowly pursued by a strange and creepy stalker, known only as, The Slender Man. The game recieved universal praise for it's minimalist horror elements, sound design, and ambition. The game was released in June of 2012 as a free game. However, after more than 2,000,000 downloads were reported of the sleeper hit, a sequel from the original developers immediately began production. It was no later than March of 2013 that Slender: The Arrival was released - a highly anticipated "sequel" to Slender, only this time, for pay. No one knew exactly what to expect, so when Slender: The Arrival only recieved lukewarm reception from it's many hungry fans, I personally was disappointed. I with-held from playing the game for a long while, until I saw it was available on Steam, and decided to give it a try. I'll say though, that despite Slender: The Arrival being well worth your time, there still is much disappointment to be had. The story this time around focuses on Lauren, a young lady visiting her friend Kate in order to help her clear out and sell an old house in the woods belonging to her now deceased Mother. Once Lauren arrives at the home though, after a mild car collision, Kate is nowhere to be found. As Lauren investigates, she realizes that Kate may have been kidnapped by a supernatural entity. Soon, Lauren realizes that she too is being stalked, and must work her way through the forest to a mysterious radio tower. Once again, the sound design is superb, and the gameplay is simple, but effective. However, the element that took me most by surprise was just how beautifully rendered the settings were. After completing a tough challenge that requires difficult work and replays over and over again, there's nothing more rewarding than a pleasent stride through the great outdoors, even if they are being occupied by The Slender Man. The biggest problem with the game is, unfortunately, it's length. Though Slender: The Eight Pages is obviously a very short game, it makes up for it in the difficulty. I personally have never beat Slender, but I still try. The problem in this games design is the fact that it's only made out of 6 short stages, but each is made to be extremely difficult, and take a trial and error process. In addition, the story feels lacking as well. Though written by the superb Marble Hornets team, the story still feels anti-climactic, and unfinished, giving us hints of a much larger puzzle, but only revealing limited pieces. In the end though, the gameplay is scary, and fun, and I suppose that's all that matters. Recommended.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												It took me about 2 1/2 hours to finish the game the first time. I played on "easy," because I wanted to experience the game settings and "mythos" elements. I found it to be very atmospheric, creepy, and surprisingly pretty. As a fan of the Slenderman mythology, it was very satisfying.It is certainly story-lite, I would say. There is a common thread running through the levels which is supported by documents and a couple of clever flash-back mechanisms, but the story is definitely not well fleshed out. If it had been, and if the game had been longer, it would have been gold. As it stands, if you like Slenderman stuff, or if you just like creepy, atmospheric games, this is a good one, I would catch it on sale because its very short, but in general its worth a shot. I am currently playing through it a second time on "normal," because a little more challenge would be nice, and because I failed to get all of the documents the first time through. So, it also has replay value, which is nice, especially in a short game. I should also mention that I happily had no technical issues with this game, which is rare enough these days, It seems to be solidly made by people who were interested in their subject matter. Kudos.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												As a large fan of horror games, I have a huge problem with them. Most horror games rely on the initial shock of whatever it is you're dealing with. In this case, the whatever it is you're dealing with is Slender Man. He's creepy and extremely startling. He'll scare you to death the first run through this game. Slender, or better yet the mechanics that make up Slender, rely on the unknown and the confusion that's conjured in your own head. Being lost AND hunted make for a stressful situation. And they only lay it on thicker as you continue. But after the first playthrough, you know exactly what to expect and you know exactly how Slender and his hooded companion are going to react to you and your actions. The shock wears off and you're left only a little startled every time your camera lense gets a bit of static. All of that boils down to the lack of any real replayability. Nothing is left to keep you wondering except a few collectables. If you are looking for story in this game, almost the entire narrative is found within the many collectables found in the game. The collectables and the narrative found within those collectables adds a very miniscule amount of replayability. Which brings me to my conclusion; I think this game is very worthy of its $9.99 price tag, but doesn't have much more to offer after the experience.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												I love this game, and believe it or not I'm actually pretty big on Creepypasta and whatnot. The story of Kate the Chaser is one of my favorites, and I'm not actually sure if it's been fully solved, I even had some trouble with that one.I've seen a lot of people mistaking Kate for Jeff the Killer. That's uh, cute. Jeff is mentioned nowhere in the game, the only Creepypastas in Slender: The Arrival are Slenderman himself, Kate the Chaser, and Charlie.Now to review the game itself. Is it scary? Not to me, but then again, I'm not scared easily, and this game is pretty old anyway, so the scare factor and fandom has died down a lot. This game has a great story, and this makes a great follow-up to Slender: The Eight Pages, which is also a part of Kate's story. I find this game to be amazingly challenging though, at least when you actually meet Kate as an antagonist, and you have to deal with her AND Slenderman. I also really like the music to this game, it's a bit depressing, but it fits the game. If you're looking for something with a good mystery, and you like Creepypasta, then this game is for you. I highly recommend it.9/10.
