Posted: June 29, 2014
												Slender starts off decent enough but quickly devolves into something pointless and irritating. The repetitive gameplay is only slightly improved from the first game, and the story, while it certainly has potential, is rushed and just doesn't quite make sense in the end. The atmosphere is eerie enough, but the game doesn't use that to its advantage. There's no slow build of suspense or horror. They just throw everything at you, repeatedly, to the point where there's just no scare or thrill to it anymore (if there ever was). In the end, I was mainly relieved the game was so short.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												A horrible copypaste galore of jumpscares and random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.The prologue of this game is actually the scariest part, seeing that you don't know what to expect if you haven't played it before. But after that, the game just takes you back to a remake of the old "find the 8 pages while running from slender" game.It should be needless to say, but this is only remotely scary one time because you don't know what to look out for. But as the gameplay escalates after finding more pages, it immediately turns into tedious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.You may be looking for the final 8 page several times just to have slender magically teleport from behind you right in front of your face and block your only way to get to the last part. This is not scary, this is not thought out gameplay. This is just complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t when you suddenly have to trek around the map until luck decides that you may pass to the last part without getting randomly instakilled by something you can do absolutely nothing about.I had hopes that the game would turn into something with more and better gameplay after the 8 pages part, but it's the exact same formula repeated yet again. Except find the stated number of the new type of item while avoiding slender and yet another extra monster at the same time.It's not funny, it's not scary and it's just a randomized game of tag where you are chased by a no-clipping hacker with teleport. Stay away from this unless you really like jumpscares and copypaste gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Ok, graphics and sound effects, I will give a total PLUS! I had the chicken skin going and everything.But as  a gamer with ADHD, this really is a challenge. It should feature a god dam RUN button.. Walking is really time consuming and I find that I was losing attention quickly.Especiall when you die and restart. That is just torture in itself.But the run feature as well to avoid confrontations. Seriously, in real life, one would run away from danger. But this character when you confront danger, you still just "walk away" like tomorrow is another day.As for defence... Well there is nothing you can do, you get attacked and you are dead. Simple.Would be cool to have something. This would probably be a better game as a fps game. I know that it's not designed to be that way. Just a suggestion or a mod added to it would make this more fun to play like Alien VS Predator 2... Also, achievements. Gaming companies need to stop making achivements like completed NIGHTMARE level. Not everyone can do it and don't want to do it. The fact that you finish the (any) game is and achievement. Sometimes, a person wants to play the game once and that's it they move on. Achievements like this is just making people play the game again for nothing on a level they don't want. Also achievements where you need to see how you die, or fail x amount of times and what not. That is really annoying. It seems they lacked imagination and focused on how to get achievements for playing bad instead of playing well.Although these are what I believe would make it a better game, it is designed for what it is and if you have the patience for it then this game is good for a good scare.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
 My Rating: 6.5/10 I mean, honestly, the game could've, and would've, been better if they would just make it longer. I played the game once on my friends account, and I finished it a little bit pass the one hour mark.Sure, there was a relatively good plot, amongst its amazing graphics, great gameplay, and many many more, but the length is just way to short. That's basically it.Gameplay - 8/10 - there was a variety of different objectives throughout the game, which is awesome, but it gets a bit repetitive, first there was the "walk-around-the-house-and-explore-and-avoid-the-spooky-as-fudge-Slenderman" part of the game, then, you get the best part, the part where you get to walk around the forest looking for notes, then you start looking for generators (just like what you did in the first part), and you end with running into a burning lighthouse. It gets a little bit repetitive, and it is a bit short, but it was a good experience.Graphics - 9/10 -  the amount of attention they put in the development of the game was absolutely stunning, the details are extremely realistic, there's nothing more I could say.Story - 6/10 - meh, its okay.Length - 3/10 - OH MY GOD, NO.Overall - 6.5/10

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												VERSION 2.0 Review:Slender The Arrival has certainly had shifts in quality between updates, and I am pleased to say that v2.0 is literally perfect. First off, the new levels are TERRIFYING. And I mean Amnesia terrifying, Homestead and Memories (the two new levels) are very memorable and are a great addition to the game. The Arrival looked amazing upon release, and yet v2.0 makes it look even better. There are better textures and models in some areas, and Genesis now looks fantastic rather than being a carbon copy of The Eight Pages with some of The Arrival's entities. The biggest flaw to S:TA before v2.0 was the gameplay; it was ridden by bugs and problems such as the overly frustrating mine level, terrible interaction physics, and the simply god awful fire sequence. Everything has been fixed in 2.0. The interaction is now smooth and comfortable, the mine level's main NPC (the source of the frustration) has been perfected, and the fire sequence is now an intense but fair climax. Some gamers may be turned off by the ten dollar price tag for a 3 hour game, but guys, come on. A group of inexperienced indie developers worked their asses off for this and they deserve the money. Not to mention, this is one of the horror greats in gaming - I liked it almost as much as the Amnesia games. This is also the first game by Blue Isle Studios, and for an indie game group's first game this is amazing. Overall it's an amazing game with a great story. Give it a go.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												When I first played Slender: The Eight Pages however many years ago it was now, I was instantly smitten. And also really scared. So being the typical consumer that I like to think I am, I bought this game before it came to everyone's beloved platform, Steam. Let me say one thing: It has come so far from then. New levels, bug fixes, level edits. The list goes on. All of these things have made the game a more enjoyable experience for players like me. It is not comparable to something like Outlast, at least for me, due to the factors of human nature brought up in that game (humans have the capabilities to be far more monstrous than any supernatural beings, in my humble opinion). However, the game is still terrifying. And short. I am saddened to say that I think my time playing may have been my whole playthrough. Not on hardcore, but on regualr mode. That said I had played through the game before, so much of it was already known to me. All in all, a top-notch Slenderman game. As a horror game, probably around the middle to upper-middle class, the kind that still would have qualified for the guillotine in the French Revolution but only by the length of their necks. As a story, its a bit weak. Gameplay is your typical run and hide without the hiding and with a lot more of the running. I definitely recommend this game to horror fans, although due to its length maybe consider getting it on sale (I ain't telling you how to live your life, just a thought though).

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												When Slender: The Eight Pages was released in the summer of 2012, horror fans praised its short, experimental, and completely free take on the genre. Manically dashing through the forest and trying to snag all eight pieces of paper before the creepy Slender Man finds you remains a surprisingly unnerving experience. Cut to spring of 2013, and we now have Slender: The Arrival on PC. This paid-for sequel attempts to pump up the horror experiment into a bigger (though still quite short) game, but it quickly becomes apparent that the simple mechanics of the original Slender crumble under the weight.Most importantly, The Arrival remembers that the core of any good horror lies in its boogeyman. The Slender Man himself still stalks you with the same terrifying persistence he has in the original, exuding a menacing presence that evolves throughout the story in some unexpected ways. Though his iconic design may be simple, I still got freaked out every time I spotted his silhouette in the distance. You can't fight him, only run from him, and that in of itself makes him more frightening than most game monsters.The world he haunts is larger and denser, as well. Instead of a dark forest, you’ll wander through abandoned homes, creepy mines, and sunbaked hillsides. Some of the better-lit areas look genuinely great. Trekking through autumnal forests and rummaging through homes that actually feel lived in make the world of Slender an interesting environment.Some impressive sound design surrounds you with an ambient soundtrack and jarring noises, and it really adds to the already creepy atmosphere. Boards creak, children whisper, and there are some truly terrifying moments that wouldn’t exist without the impeccable use of audio. Like all great horror games, Slender is best served in a dark room with a pair of headphones.These parts, at least, are done pretty well... but it's simply not enough. While I appreciate the lengths that developer Blue Isle went to flesh things out, The Arrival relies far too heavily on the rudimentary game mechanics of the original, which was only ever meant to last for a few minutes. Like its predecessor, the vast majority of The Arrival essentially boils down to finding a certain number of objects while an increasingly dangerous enemy stalks you. Whether it’s pieces of paper in a forest or generators in a mine, you’re repeating the exact same actions in every part of The Arrival. It feels like being asked to finish a Where’s Waldo book while your house burns down around you.The fact that I got tired of it during a game this short shows just how repetitive The Arrival is. While a lucky player can dash through in about 20 minutes, it’ll probably take most people a few hours thanks to the unfair nature of the enemies. Slender Man and his minions don’t mind warping directly behind you and causing instant game over. The worst offender of this comes once you reach the abandoned mine and are introduced to a second enemy type. The Proxy, a creepy knife-wielding kid, stalks you throughout the level as you (yup, you guessed it) once again attempt to find a series of objects. He continually killed me with no warning whatsoever, which as you might imagine, gets pretty frustrating.Although the mine level was genuinely spooky at first, it and many other areas quickly lose their terrifying charm once you’re forced to replay them dozens of times. I appreciate games that are tough yet fair, but those that arbitrarily punish their players sabotage their own fun. This problem persists throughout Slender: The Arrival. The horrifying atmosphere that Blue Isle manages to create is consistently squandered by dull mechanics and unfair difficulty spikes.The VerdictSlender: The Arrival manages to deliver some truly impressive scares, but you’ll have to wade through the muck of repetitive tasks and unfair enemies in order to experience them. I found more enjoyment in playing the free original installment, which delivers a powerful horror experience without the annoyances and filler. By trying to stretch the initial concept over five separate scenarios, Slender only succeeds in proving that some ideas are better left in the experimental phase.~cmaexi 24.06.2016

												If there's such a thing as a casual horror game then this is it. The first half of the game is much more ambient and thus scarier than the second half. Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game is a pretty good sequel to the Eight Pages, which everyone knows and loves. In this game, you play alongside a decent, albeit short, story of Slender's torment. Gameplay is solid, and there are two levels that are pretty similar to the first game (excluding the remake level at the end). There are other filler story chapters, but chapters 2 and 3 really stand out amongst the rest of them. Although Slender is definitely more aggressive (you'll more than likely see him more often this time around) and there are new enemies, I've found the progression to be much easier. Now, that being said, I'm sure thats for story purposes, so you can finish the game, but even the remake level we got all 8 pages on the first try without seeing Slender even once. This game is definitely interesting and chapter 3 definitely caught us off guard the first time around, but for pure entertainment purposes, the first game is superior. All that said, my largest gripe with this game is that most of the story has to be obtained by easily missable and ignorable collectables. There is almost no story if you don't find and interact with the various collectables throughout the game. If you love the Slender lore this is a decent buy, but otherwise if you are just playing for the Eight Page level, stick to the first. 7/10

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Found the game to be quite enjoyable. The graphics were amazing comprared to older versions and the addition of a "Chaser" was something special that hightened the tension. The story is portrayed via the notes you find and the secret chapters you play in, which makes an explorer type like me happy since I really like to look around and find every little hidden item. The soundtrack did a very good job of immersing me into the game and the ambient noise from the scraping to the water droplets was well implemented and complimented the atmosphere that the various areas had. The game is well worth any price you find it at today and has great replay value. Highly recommend the game for anyone who is a fan of Slenderman or anyone who wants to try something different. Have fun and enjoy the ride as you get to explore a world of danger and jumpscares.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game really has nothing going for it. Give it a try if it's ever free but it's definitely not worth your money. Maybe this is due to the fact that I've played through plenty of games that do what this game tries to do but far more successfully, such as Amnesia or Outlast. Or maybe it's that everything is extremely predictable. Or perhaps it's the fact that on a first run you'll beat this game between 1-2 hours.  Those issues aside the main issue lies in the enemy(s) your running from. Neither of which leave you feeling the urgency to run. Slenderman himself is laughably predictable and easy to evade while the second enemy you encounter both runs slower than you and can be stunned indefinitely with just your flashlight, so the entire time never feeling like much of a threat. I think the scariest part of this game happened when the level broke due to a glitch and had to be restarted.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												You leave your vehicle as you begin your search to find Kate with the sun sinking beyond the horizon, leaving you stranded in an ominous environment, where you are far from being in control of things. From the beginning He makes his point to let you know that he is upon you since the darkness has swallowed the woods, and you, who is completely at his mercy, must scavenge through the abyss of the dark thicket to find the classic 8 pages, only to find that there is more horror than you could imagine.This is a wonderful game, with some new twists on the classic Slender. The game has the classic ominous feel as Slendy stalks you thought the woods and you gather the 8 pages, with each page another layer of soundtrack and a more aggressive foe, building up the anticipation of the end, only bringing you to more discoveries. In which new discoveries you get to encounter a new foe that hounds you more violently than our beloved classic.

Posted: March 6, 2014
												There are parts of this game that are not that scary. Then there are parts that are absolutely horrifying. One in particular is the "Into the Abyss" level. I can take Slender popping out unexpectedly and giving me a jump while I look for pages, but there is something about being chased by a masked psycho on foot through dark hallways while hearing their footsteps and breathing, especially when you don't see them yet, that terrifies me down to my core. I've only been able to complete that level once, but I get the urge to shut the game off each time I re-enter those mines. I hear the steps and that breathing, and I lose all composure I had. That right there is the sign of a great horror game. Slender: The Arrival is short, but what is there is wonderfully presented and paced, with some fantastic visuals and chilling atmosphere. With free DLC on the way, Slender: The Arrival is looking to become one of the best indie horror games in years. For fans of the original Slender: The Eight Pages and the Slenderman's Shadow series, it is a must play.

												Definitely one of the scariest games I've ever played.  When the original Slender came out, I nearly poo'ed myself, then it was re-released with higher production values into what is "Slender: The Arrival".  The mechanics of the game are fairly shallow and it really has almost no replayability, once you know the scares and story, but it is definitely worth the single ride.  Play at night with the sound up and lights out.  You'll be hard-pressed to find a more intense horror experience outside of Alien Isolation ;-)

												This is one of the best horror games I've ever played. Although it's not very long, it definitely has replay value. Posted: June 29, 2015
												For those of you hesitating - it is a game to play in the dark rainy evening. Installed it and wanted to try it together with my gf. For the first part - the prologue - it does not seem to be that scary, most of the time you are just getting used to the rules set by the game, learn the simple mechanics.But in the second part - "the 8 pages" - that is when♥♥♥♥♥♥got real.You dont shoot here, simply try to outrun the overwhelming creepy man in a suit in dark forests/buildings with only a flashlight.For those of you who want more challenge - set your difficlty to hard - that is where the flashlight has limited battery and you begin to panic when it is about to run out.Recommend it as a cool horror game for a couple of dark nights8/10

Posted: June 26, 2015
												Simply a great horror game.An 'expanded version' of the indie horror classic Slender: The Eight Pages, developers Blue Island managed to keep the dread feeling the from the first game.Containing better graphics, more variety of levels, and some surprises, Slender: The Arrival somehow manages to keep the feeling of dread, of being watched, of being stalked while being out in the woods. Although it's a short game (about 2 hours if you wander through the levels to find all the collectibles) the pacing is good. The horror Slenderman causes on us this time is backed by a story. It is quite basic, but it helps to build the tension until you reach its climax. The game has some memorable moments, like a tense section in the mines and a re-make of the classic 8 pages search. In overall, it offers a solid gaming experience for the fans of horror games, it's worth replaying it to get all the collectibles that expand the story and has different difficulties available.Oh, and this time, Slendy comes with some friends. And you will not want to play with them.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												A few minor spoilers if you can really call them that are ahead:Let me make one thing perfectly clear before a few of my sentences are taken wrong: I absolutely love this game. I like how we had tat like Silent Hill Homecoming (just for the record big fan of the SH games, just not Downpour or Homecoming, or even The Room for that matter though it was nice.) and we had stuff that was basically jumpscare after jumpscare.This game restored my faith in the Survival Horror genre. I was terrified all the way through, even that first walk to the house in the beginning scared me quite a bit because this game has ATMOSPHERE. Jumpscares, scares in general, are mostly effective when there's an atmosphere. The main setting (outside) is absolutely beautiful but my main problem with the game is the Into The Abyss level.I was so♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the first three times of dying that I nearly tore my hair out. I played this, regrettably, on Xbox before I got it here. When I got past Slender Man I was happy as a f***ing peach and then... then Into The Abyss happened. It was absolute hell for me to get through, but admittedly it felt rewarding to get through. The level was quite hard to do, yes I realize this was meant to be but this could have been toned down a little. Other than that I have absolutely no problems with this game. The scares are effective and frequent enough to make me yelp but not too frequent to bore me, the atmosphere is dripping off the screen, the story is interesting, and the design for both level and characters are friggin' amazing. All in all, I would rate this game 9/10 in total for atmosphere, mechanics, graphics, and story. I especially loved seeing Slender man after his original game Slender The Eight Pages come back in even more slender glory. Would I recommend this game? Absolutely. Despite the inevitable frustration with the ITB level the rest of the game, while very short, made it all worth the time I spent in it. As soon as you can get your hands on this, no matter what platform, make sure this is on your list.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												I was first introduced to "Slenderman" by a co-worker back in 2010 when the original Something Awful creepy-pasta contest entry was just starting to gain some meme-level ground.  I spent a late night after closing at the drug store we were employed at looking over all of the classic photoshops of a tall, thin man holding the hands of children and appearing just out of the foreground in old black and white photos.  Browsing creepy-pastas and looking at a picture trying to find "the monster" somewhere in the trees became a bit of a spooky "Eye Spy" game.  My curiousity in the concept of Slenderman would eventually lead me, like many intrepid fans, to Marble Hornets.  This isn't the outlet to critique THAC's series, but if you're interested in the writing style employed in Slender: The Arrival (STA), I would suggest looking it up on YouTube.  About two years later, Slender: The Eight Pages (STEP) hit the scene and started blowing up online when "Let's Play" style shows and streams started to pick up steam in the gaming community.  I'll admit, STEP often lead me to facepalm when a professor would ask inquistively to the class "what's a slender man?" and a half dozen classmates would respond "its this game-", etc.  My roommates and I still ended up downloading the game and plugging a laptop into our 36" Vizio on Halloween night 2012 to properly get spooked out.  The screams eventually died out by midnight as the novelty wore off and we started to figure out how to game the AI, but I digress.  I'm offering all of this information up as I feel that my familiarity with Slenderman (the creepy-pastas, the various YouTube shows, the movie, etc.) greatly impacts my reccomendation for this game.  If you're unfamiliar with the whole concept of Slenderman this might not be the best way to start into those (sometimes super spooky) waters.  STA, while not a perfect execution, really manages to nail a few of its key components.  The levels go back and forth between variations on the original STEP gameplay with "collecting" something randomly placed around the map while avoiding a stalking, and increasingly aggressive enemy, and what some may "lovingly" refer to as a "walking simulator".  Both gameplay styles are evenly paced out so neither have enough time to grow stale in long bursts.  The exploration levels, and well, the entire game looks gorgeous.  The environments stay with you in this game, even after a week after I completed my playthrough I still remember the striking landscapes more than anything else.  Various collectable pamphlets, emails, etc. dot the maps and help build out the core cast and their history.  I would reccomend tracking these down as they provide most of the world building and really highlight the writing contributions provided by THAC for the game's script.  The player controlled character can feel kind of clunky and slow at times, and I undestand the limited endurance was a design decision to prevent constant sprinting away from enemies but in the portions without something to avoid this can feel somewhat limiting.  The graphics for props, buildings, etc. aren't anything to write home about, but the wilderness and skyboxes always manage to look gorgeous.  Finally, I think my main issue with this game is that after my first death at the hands of Slenderman (or The Operator, or whatever) the scare factor had mostly worn off.  Again, I attribute this to already being burnt out on STEP and other Slenderman series.  The model's head just doesn't seem right either, especially with the more defined cheek bones.  I prefer Slenderman to only have a human silohuette and no other details in the face, but again, that's a personal preference.So, if you liked STEP (and speaking of which, this game contains an HD remaster of that level unlocked after beating the main story), or are just a fan of anything Slenderman I'd reccomend this.  Its no AAA horror game, but its a competent couple hour romp.

												While the game was a bit shorter than i expected it to be the immersive game play the story and the searching for all the stuff you need plus dificult senerios that you have to handle and the scares and uneasyness this game gives off i strongly recomend it to anyone who is a fan of horror games or even jump scares

Posted: November 1, 2015
												The graphics are nice, and I am a fan of the Slenderman.  I can never fully rationalize away my fears, because he strongly resembles a childhood recurring nightmare that I had.  (A long, pale figure, with empty eyes looking into the window, unmoving, unblinking.)  I think this may be some kind of universal brain-glitch that we have as human beings.  LOTS of people feared similar creatures, whether things they imagined themselves, or things from various mythologies in different parts of the world.But having gone through the introduction, and knowing Slenderman, who is by now a meme, I was not at all frightened, when I could flick my flashlight on and off at him in the first stage, and even stare dead at him, without so much as a flicker of movement or threat.  This is a great way to yank me out of any sense of suspense and tension.  And the way you start a game really has a great deal of impact on the way the rest of it feels.  So eh, 2/10.  Good graphics, story seems like it'd be good?  But poor setup, and stage 2 is a rehash of a free game.  Shouldn't have to go through an hour of boring/ rehashed material to get to the good stuff.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												Such was the massive success of the 2012 hit Slender The Eight Pages, Blue Isle decided to follow it up with a sequel, Slender The Arrival.The game begins beside your car, Lauren has arrived to visit her friend Kate who has decided to sell her mother’s house after her passing. You soon find yourself running down a road leading to Kate’s house and by the time you reach the outside walls daylight has transformed into total darkness. You find the front door of the house wide open, inside completely empty. Your first action is to search for a flash light to lift the darkness and then set about investigating Kate’s disappearance. The whole idea of being alone in this game can be pretty daunting especially when you know there is a faceless man stalking you.Slender doesn’t really appear too much in the Prologue but he makes enough of an appearance to let you know he is there and watching you. You’ll be standing still and hear gravel shifting or footsteps behind you and then my personal favourite, a door shutting by itself!.You will find clues throughout the house in the form of scrapbook items which you can collect at any point and view via the Book in the main menu, these items give you some insight into what is going on within the game.In total there are nine stages, eight of these are story related with the extra stage being a revamp of the original Eight Pages and for those not familiar with the previous game, the aim is to collect eight pages scattered around a wooded area but you have to find all eight before Slender kills you. Pages can be found tacked to objects like trees and cars and you can very quickly find yourself running in circles looking for them while praying your flashlight doesn’t run out.The game also introduces two brand new stages namely Homestead and a secret stage only revealed after finding a secret object while in the stage Flashback which itself has been split into two stages to accommodate Homestead. Now the end of Flashback is called Escape.There is also a new enemy to deal with, one that does not appear in the original release and you’ll find him on the third stage.Overall the game is very short and can be easily completed in less than an hour. Maybe what it needed was a longer and stronger storyline, one that wasn’t so repetitive. But seeing as it was already a well known game across the steam community it was to be expected that not much would change coming across to the consoles. Though with new content there is something to look forward to and of course there is the main protagonist Slender who without a doubt will make you jump when he randomly appears throughout the game and trust me, turning around to get a face full of him, turning my screen all distorted and full of static was enough to give me goosebumps or attempting to make my way through a burning forest with his tentacles appearing in front of me trying to grab me, made me wonder why I didn’t just remain in the cave.The game is a lot of fun to play, especially in a darkened room by yourself or maybe with friends I would also recommend playing it with headphones in or if you have it surround sound because it makes the experience that much scarier. If you are a fan of the games and all things Slender you shouldn’t be too disappointed and if you’re someone who has only ever heard about Slender it’s definitely worth checking out. To sum it up, if you’re looking for a storyline forget it but if you love being scared senseless while wandering around in the darkness then this should suit you down to the ground. Hopefully in the future Slender will get the retail game it surely deserves.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												------------------------------------------------------Cons & Pros:+++ Not jumpscare reliant (defines the quality of a horror game imo)++ Good graphics++ Strong atmosphere built with sounds and lighting++ Creepy villain and level design++ The only game that doesn't let you pause at random times which CREEPS ME THE ♥♥♥♥ OUT+ Collectibles if you're into that kind of thing+ Different difficulty levels- Short. I know slender games are not meant to be long but still, a game of this quality should/could have had a little more story to it. Maybe.- A little bit expensive, as you will probably play it only once or twice.Hardcore horror game players might not get scared about the stuff in this game but mediocre and casual horror players like myself can get creeped out occasionally.This game includes the original slender mechanic of collecting pages and some additional polish. Like safe areas with strong atmosphere or more background on the story.I would give this game a10/10 on graphics11/10 on sounds6/10 in length9/10 in general. Grab it on sale.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game enough! It's a perfect and well implemented horror story about a famous creepypasta. The enviroments are beautiful and well crafted, the lights and shadows are setup to give a good, uneasy vibe, and of course the experience wouldn't be complete without the monster, the Slenderman. Though the story itself is a little difficult to follow at times, especially if you cannot find the notes, its easy enough to write in your own story- to be the character, rather than pretending to be someone else. That, above all, is what drags me into this game and holds me in the tight, vice grip of fear.

												This is one of the best horror games I've ever played. Although it's not very long, it definitely has replay value. Posted: October 29, 2013
												Created by the same team behind the originial, experimental, slender: the eight pages game, Slender: the arrival is a full, nerve shredding experience, which may as well have a reward for depriving me of sleep. Both from playing, and also from not being able to sleep afterwards.While it is a very short game, there is plenty to find, after hours of playing around I still have not got all the notes. There may even be secret areas I am unaware of.Since it's arrival on steam there has been new content, which fills in some loose gaps in gameplay, while adding to the experience. It has a great atmosphere, nice graphics, is really scary and has a decent story. The one problem; it could explain more. I get that it's trying to create a sense of mystery, and it's up to you to find out the lore behind the game through fidning notes lyting around, but it could at least explain your charecters role and their backstory more immediately,  we are playing AS them, so why not know what they do?!Other than shortness and a few optimisation issues, it's a great game, and seeing as it's the first commercial release by it's creators, it's a great effort!If you love horror, go for it!

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Worth a play if you like creepy games. This game isn't terribly twisted or gross like a lot of horror games, it's just all about keeping your anxiety level high! Don't get me wrong, the story and atmosphere keep you creeped out, but what's really creepy is that, for much of the game, the slender man can appear anytime, anywhere, and all you can do is run as fast as you can in the opposite direction.It only takes a couple of hours to play through, if you're not trying to get 100% everything, but it's worth the ride.A negative would be that the story isn't all that interesting or coherent. Maybe it would make more sense if I 100%-ed the game and was able to read all the notes laying around, but really, a game should make sense without requiring that.

Posted: November 24, 2015
												This is the definitive game for the Horror genre. Psychological horror at its finest. This is like a scream of fresh air in a dark, underground cave -- compared to the unimaginative games that claim to embody fear in the form of gore. In this game you will find almost no gore. You will be scared because you are scared of fear itself. You have no big guns to protect you, no base-building or crafting that will distance you from this inevitable horror. Your skills will be put to use running, hiding, weeping with sheer terror, and piecing together the mystery behind the horror.When you're too scared to move on, load up a nice, comforting zombie shoot-'em-up to reassure yourself that it's all just a game...

Posted: November 25, 2015
												Slender: The Arrival was a rather great game. It had a complete story line to lore you in, a beautifully building atmosphere, and the graphics where absolutely STUNNING. There are little few bugs from what I've found(And trust me, the second I get a game, I like trying to break the maps to said game.), and a nice map to free explore. But by far, the best thing I found about Slender: The Arrival, HAD to be it's atmosphere. It had a great build up that left the player on edge, which made the jump scares all the more better. The rustling of the forest around you, the crunching of the leaves, or in the case of the generator level, the sound of footsteps running at you, all help immerse the player. The game uses rather nice functions of forcing the player to do what they don't want to, such as entering a building or going down a hall to grab a note, knowing they'll have to go back and he might be standing there. Although, I will say, the complaint I have about this game is that the enemies themselves often get stuck on objects while coming after you. It subtracts from the game play to know if you angel yourself right or quick turn a corner, you could get them stuck there for a moment. In Slenders case, He'll become unstuck the second you move to far away and instead transport away, but in Kate/Jeff The Killer/ Whoever the one running after you is, They could get stuck there for a good while.This game is best played in the dark, with either surround sound or headphones in for best possible outcome.Overall, I'd give it a 8.9 of 10.

Posted: April 9, 2014
												Built up from an elegantly distilled core of exploration and vulnerability, Slender: The Arrival asserts the brilliantly masochistic joy of fear.Slender: The Arrival takes its name from a relatively new urban legend: the Slender Man. Created from whole cloth by an Internet denizen, this information age monster is a far cry from anything in the classical pantheon. His unique mythology and strangely broad appeal meant that it didn't take long for the eerie figure to make his way to video games. Slender: The Eight Pages, The Arrival's predecessor, was an exceptionally well-made title of a concept that became somewhat of a YouTube sensation.  Thousands of individuals posted videos of themselves wandering through an eerie forest coveted in fog, searching for eight pieces of paper with only a flashlight to guide them. An approximate successful run took about thirty minutes, but the pure sense of helplessness in the face of an unknown threat became the foundation for this well-realized sequel.The primary focus on weakness and exploration, The Arrival expands on the ideas of its predecessor with a basic story, and the creative application of familiar mechanics. The game is broken up into five chapters, each one with its own focus. You play as Lauren, a young woman driving to see her friend, Kate. Shortly before the events of the game, Kate's mother passed away. On Lauren's journey to Kate's house, her path is obscured by a fallen tree. Committing hte worst sin in any horror series, she continues the rest of the way on foot, carrying a high definition camcorder with her.Two hours into the game, it isn't so long that the constant apprehension becomes tiring. There is a smattering of collectibles to flesh out hte backstory, however because taking extra time to carefully scrutinize for them places you at even greater danger, you are forced to weigh narrative cohesion against survival. The lure of these collectables is subtle at best, however it adds value and keeps you from becoming too comfortable with the world. After all, if there was no real, tangible danger, the Slender Man would not be an effective monster.As a sort-of myth born from the Internet, Slender Man is likely one of the first genuinely compelling monsters to grace pop culture in a long time. The related games and their variants and mods, as well as the stories and the YouTube series surrounding them, shows the genesis of 21st century folklore. A little rough around the edges, The Arrival is simply fascinating because it plays on modern fears through a modern medium. For that, it has managed to breathe new life into a genre once through to be dead. Slender is not an experience you will soon forget, and priced at ten dollars, its just about right for its short lived tale. A word of advice, be sure to play at night with headphones for the full effect. Best regards!

												You leave your vehicle as you begin your search to find Kate with the sun sinking beyond the horizon, leaving you stranded in an ominous environment, where you are far from being in control of things. From the beginning He makes his point to let you know that he is upon you since the darkness has swallowed the woods, and you, who is completely at his mercy, must scavenge through the abyss of the dark thicket to find the classic 8 pages, only to find that there is more horror than you could imagine.This is a wonderful game, with some new twists on the classic Slender. The game has the classic ominous feel as Slendy stalks you thought the woods and you gather the 8 pages, with each page another layer of soundtrack and a more aggressive foe, building up the anticipation of the end, only bringing you to more discoveries. In which new discoveries you get to encounter a new foe that hounds you more violently than our beloved classic.

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Slender: The Arrival is the official expanded version of Slender: The Eight Pages. It meant to have a story behind why the Slender Man is after you, and a few others. What do I think of this game you may ask? Well, this review will cover that.First off, I will start with the setting and character's. The game take's place in an unspecified state of America. Most of it take's place in park with a radio tower and a mine complex. Now on to the character's. The game's protagonist is Lauren, a woman looking for her missing friend named Kate, who has recently disappeared. A man only known as CR can be read about in the in-game collectibles.He apeared to be somehow involved with Kate and the Slender Man, whom does not need an introduction.The next thing I want to cover is the overall gameplay. I think it is both good and bad. I will start the good. The atmosphere is probably the best part of the the game. It gave me an unsettling feeling throughout the game. Another great thing about The Arrival is the genuinely creepy music. It gets more and more tense as you complete the objectives. And also, not being able to fight back can also keep some people on edge.Now for the bad. Unfortunately, there are more bad aspects than you might be thinking. Let's start with the objectives. Pretty much every level involves somehow interacting with a certain amount of objects. It does'nt take very long for the game to start feeling quite repetitive. While a recent update added two new levels to branch off from this, those two levels are'nt very good and may leave quite a bit of gamers feel pretty unsatisfied after completing them. Another thing I will cover is the overall scares. They start out great, but lose their charm less than halfway through the game. The Slendern Man himself begins to dwindle as the as the game progresses. While he seems terrifying at first, he later starts to become less and less scary to the point that you can easily walk past him and not have even the slightest sense of fear. The two new enemies added also begin to have this effect. The hooded person at first seems pretty scary, but it's cheap jump scare attack becomes pretty un-scary and rather just annoying and cheaply animated. The skeletal figure is also pretty unsettling, but soon just apears to be a generic horror cliche. Another thing is the game's incredibly short length. The game can easily be finished in less than two hours, incuding the bonus level.The VerdictSlender: The Arrival simply feels rushed. The music and atmosphere are great, but the repetitive gameplay, cheap scare's, and extremely short length just ruins the experience. If you want a cheap and short horror game, buy Slender: The Arrival. If you want quality scares and fun gameplay, look elswhere.  Overall, 5/10

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Probably the scariest game I have ever played. Don't expect complex gameplay or intense puzzle-solving or anything like that, you should just expect to wet your pants after a while. Most of the game is just spent exploring and looking to collect a set number of items (similiar to the mod this game was based off), however don't think that means this game is boring. The game developers excel in knowing how to properly f%$k your mind while you attempt to avoid being scared. I actually have difficulty playing this game for very long at once, because I get so nervous.One of the most outstanding parts of this game is its replayability. You would think that a game like this would have little to none; you would be wrong. The developers again excel at finding ways to make each playthrough unique, hiding items in different locations and having scares randomly generated during your playthrough. Just because you were safe in an area before means nothing the next playthrough!! One of the only downsides to this is that the game is a little bit more difficult than you would expect. Finding the locations of the items before getting killed (or giving up in fear of having a heart attack) can be frustrating when their locations change every time you die, however there is usually a pattern that can be discerned eventually.While this might not be the most 'fun' or 'addictive' scary game I've ever played, I would say hands-down it is the 'scariest'. I still enjoy watching my girlfriend play it and watching her scream when she turns around and slenderman is standing right behind her. If you are someone who enjoys torturing yourself through voluntary fear, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!

Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game is a pretty good sequel to the Eight Pages, which everyone knows and loves. In this game, you play alongside a decent, albeit short, story of Slender's torment. Gameplay is solid, and there are two levels that are pretty similar to the first game (excluding the remake level at the end). There are other filler story chapters, but chapters 2 and 3 really stand out amongst the rest of them. Although Slender is definitely more aggressive (you'll more than likely see him more often this time around) and there are new enemies, I've found the progression to be much easier. Now, that being said, I'm sure thats for story purposes, so you can finish the game, but even the remake level we got all 8 pages on the first try without seeing Slender even once. This game is definitely interesting and chapter 3 definitely caught us off guard the first time around, but for pure entertainment purposes, the first game is superior. All that said, my largest gripe with this game is that most of the story has to be obtained by easily missable and ignorable collectables. There is almost no story if you don't find and interact with the various collectables throughout the game. If you love the Slender lore this is a decent buy, but otherwise if you are just playing for the Eight Page level, stick to the first. 7/10

Posted: July 29, 2014
												I have certain "phases" that I go through on the internet. I find something that I think is interesting, I obsess about it for a few months, then find another interesting thing, etc. Currently, the phase for me right now is Slender Man. For the past few months, I have gone through all of Marble Hornets, all of DarkHarvest00 and all of TribeTwelve (in that order). I plan to binge on EverymanHYBRID next. My Point is, I wanted an interactive version of these stories. Not just "Find x amount of pages," no. I wanted a Slender Man game with a story. And this game gave me exactly that.If your not that into the Slender Man/Slender Man Mythos, then the story for this game might be confusing. Very confusing. I have seen many people say that the story is bad, that it's one of the low parts of the game. I disagree. I love the story behind it, as it's vague and only creates more questions. That's what a Slender Man based story should do- it should make you think. It should stick with you, long after you finish the game/show/book.Now, I'm going to stop blabbering about the story, and actually give a review:First off, the graphics. From what I've seen, the graphics are great. The way the sun falls though the trees, the leaves flowing through the breeze- it's wonderful. And the Slender Man himself has much more detail than in "Slender: The Eight Pages." He doesn't look like he has an egg for a head, which is a plus. He looks creepy and just that feeling of something that almost looks human, but doesn't. The graphics on lower settings look crappy though, but thats to be expected.Next is audio/sound effects. Great as well. The game has a great soundtrack, which really gives you that feeling of dread and isolation, but at the right moments. There are even parts of the game where you can hear crunching leaves, as if someone- or something- is following you. It adds to the game's atmosphere a whole bunch, which is very important for a horror game. The audio distortion (that occurs when Slender Man is nearby) is scary and is much better than just static.Next is Gameplay. This part of the game was sort of a let down. Pretty much all throughout the game, all your doing is "collecting x amount of pages" or "turning on x amount of generators." It gets boring and repetitive, and sometimes annoying. I've rage quit multiple times because of this. Hopefully it is worked on in the next patch, which will add 2 more levels.And finally, Atmosphere. As said before, the audio and visuals really add to the atmosphere. You hear the eerie squeaking of violins play, as you run around in an abandoned mine, hearing the footsteps and strange coughing-like noises of someone behind you. You walk through an abandoned house, doors left open, strange scribbling on the walls. The radio is left on, and all you hear is a song filled with static echo throughout the house. This game can be terrifying, even if you are collecting pages.All in all, I find Slender: The Arrival to be a good game with flaws; the game could be longer. But still, I recommend this game to any fan of the Slender Man Mythos.01110011011001010110010101110011011110010110111101110101

Posted: November 6, 2014
												If there is a game more or the same feel and atmosphere as Amnesia, as Silent Hill (along those pretty classic horror lines)...THE ARRIVAL is among those games.- First off the game has beautifully composed music, greatly developed ambient sounds, the look and feel. Even with barely anything else other than "search, collect and survive", the game never fails to disappoint or bore (how could it possibly do that?) - Helplesness is the key element here...terror is the main goal directed towards us (the player) and shocks, oh don't worry....there are aplenty.- I don't wanna spoil it for people who haven't (or are for some reason scared to play the game), but know one thing...all future buyers...if you love horror (SURVIVAL HORROR) minus the firearms and meaningless combat implemented, you will certainly love and are gonna get utterly scared (or pleased in a perverse way^^) of Slender: THE ARRIVAL. You will like it...you might love it....you are gonna JUMP from JOY of it...He's...waiting...for....you....END OF REVIEW...

Posted: November 9, 2014
												Let's begin with this,You drive to your friends house, the house is almost pitch black aside from a few very dim lights spread across the first floor of house, one in the living room, one in the dining room, and the last in the kitchen. Thankfully you have your trusty flashlight, and your video camera. Not a sound could be heard in the entire house, you carefully walk up the stairs into the second floor, and into the last room down the hall. You walk in, and pages are scattered across the room and the window broken. you pick up one specific page that tells you to go to the woods, then you hear a loud scream coming from behind the gate in the backyard, you run to the window to investigate and see a tall slender man, standing there watching you from outside the window. as soon as you attempt to readjust your eyes, it is gone.And so we now know what we are going up against, the terror begins.Slender: The Arrival is a brilliant horror game that add's so much to what Slender: The Eight Pages lacked, a story, stunning graphics, more scares, and a whole lot more to do, with secret levels, collectibles, and fun achievements to go after. Slender is a very good horror game that brings much to the table, and on par (and possibly better) than Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs but not as involved as Amnesia: The Dark Descent. All in all, This game is definitely worth playing8/10

Posted: January 12, 2014
												I ran out of clean pants to wear playing this game. I woke up with stiff muscles because I'd been so tense. It's not just Slendy anymore. There are new enemies, new challenges, new graphics, and new music. All of these add to the suspence and diarrhea inducing climate of Slender: The Arrival. If you have the money hanging around and you enjoy horror games, I recomend this. Games like Amnesia are scary, but they take time to get you into the game. Slender: The Arrival throws you head first into a vat of "Omfg it's getting dark out and I have no idea what I'm doing". This is a game where you know something's chasing you, you know something's going to pop out at you, but you still jump and scream like a cooked lobster when it happens. The game stays true to the original but adds other aspects, other levels of scary. I highly recommend this game if you want a heart racing experience and you're into wearing diapers. Just when you think it can't get worse, it does. Worth every penny.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												I was first introduced to "Slenderman" by a co-worker back in 2010 when the original Something Awful creepy-pasta contest entry was just starting to gain some meme-level ground.  I spent a late night after closing at the drug store we were employed at looking over all of the classic photoshops of a tall, thin man holding the hands of children and appearing just out of the foreground in old black and white photos.  Browsing creepy-pastas and looking at a picture trying to find "the monster" somewhere in the trees became a bit of a spooky "Eye Spy" game.  My curiousity in the concept of Slenderman would eventually lead me, like many intrepid fans, to Marble Hornets.  This isn't the outlet to critique THAC's series, but if you're interested in the writing style employed in Slender: The Arrival (STA), I would suggest looking it up on YouTube.  About two years later, Slender: The Eight Pages (STEP) hit the scene and started blowing up online when "Let's Play" style shows and streams started to pick up steam in the gaming community.  I'll admit, STEP often lead me to facepalm when a professor would ask inquistively to the class "what's a slender man?" and a half dozen classmates would respond "its this game-", etc.  My roommates and I still ended up downloading the game and plugging a laptop into our 36" Vizio on Halloween night 2012 to properly get spooked out.  The screams eventually died out by midnight as the novelty wore off and we started to figure out how to game the AI, but I digress.  I'm offering all of this information up as I feel that my familiarity with Slenderman (the creepy-pastas, the various YouTube shows, the movie, etc.) greatly impacts my reccomendation for this game.  If you're unfamiliar with the whole concept of Slenderman this might not be the best way to start into those (sometimes super spooky) waters.  STA, while not a perfect execution, really manages to nail a few of its key components.  The levels go back and forth between variations on the original STEP gameplay with "collecting" something randomly placed around the map while avoiding a stalking, and increasingly aggressive enemy, and what some may "lovingly" refer to as a "walking simulator".  Both gameplay styles are evenly paced out so neither have enough time to grow stale in long bursts.  The exploration levels, and well, the entire game looks gorgeous.  The environments stay with you in this game, even after a week after I completed my playthrough I still remember the striking landscapes more than anything else.  Various collectable pamphlets, emails, etc. dot the maps and help build out the core cast and their history.  I would reccomend tracking these down as they provide most of the world building and really highlight the writing contributions provided by THAC for the game's script.  The player controlled character can feel kind of clunky and slow at times, and I undestand the limited endurance was a design decision to prevent constant sprinting away from enemies but in the portions without something to avoid this can feel somewhat limiting.  The graphics for props, buildings, etc. aren't anything to write home about, but the wilderness and skyboxes always manage to look gorgeous.  Finally, I think my main issue with this game is that after my first death at the hands of Slenderman (or The Operator, or whatever) the scare factor had mostly worn off.  Again, I attribute this to already being burnt out on STEP and other Slenderman series.  The model's head just doesn't seem right either, especially with the more defined cheek bones.  I prefer Slenderman to only have a human silohuette and no other details in the face, but again, that's a personal preference.So, if you liked STEP (and speaking of which, this game contains an HD remaster of that level unlocked after beating the main story), or are just a fan of anything Slenderman I'd reccomend this.  Its no AAA horror game, but its a competent couple hour romp.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												Slender: The Arrival is one of my favorite horror games I have ever played. It is incredibly terrifying and still frightens me now, even after I have beaten it, something few horror games can claim. Here is a Pros and Cons list for this game:PROS-Partially made by the original creators of Slender: The Eight Pages, and even incorporates the original game into this game's story-Terrifying antagonists. The Slenderman may be scary, but he can get a bit repetitive at times. To counteract this, two additional enemies (his proxies) exist in the game. The Chaser, and Charlie. Both of them are terrifying and nasty.-Sound design can make or break a horror game, and this game nails it on the head. The Chaser's scream will haunt you.-Pacing in this game is great. Most modern horror games go for the jumpscare, but Slender: The Arrival knows how to instill paranoia. -The mines level. You will know what I mean when you play it.-A great party horror game. You know what I mean, get a few friends together and play it, just like the original Slender.-Graphics are pretty nice in my opinion, even on low settings.CONS-I am legitimately having difficulties coming up with negative things to say about this game.RATINGSStory: 10/10Gameplay: 10/10Atmosphere: 10/10Total: 100This game is very very very good. Buy it.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												The graphics are nice, and I am a fan of the Slenderman.  I can never fully rationalize away my fears, because he strongly resembles a childhood recurring nightmare that I had.  (A long, pale figure, with empty eyes looking into the window, unmoving, unblinking.)  I think this may be some kind of universal brain-glitch that we have as human beings.  LOTS of people feared similar creatures, whether things they imagined themselves, or things from various mythologies in different parts of the world.But having gone through the introduction, and knowing Slenderman, who is by now a meme, I was not at all frightened, when I could flick my flashlight on and off at him in the first stage, and even stare dead at him, without so much as a flicker of movement or threat.  This is a great way to yank me out of any sense of suspense and tension.  And the way you start a game really has a great deal of impact on the way the rest of it feels.  So eh, 2/10.  Good graphics, story seems like it'd be good?  But poor setup, and stage 2 is a rehash of a free game.  Shouldn't have to go through an hour of boring/ rehashed material to get to the good stuff.

Posted: September 30, 2015
												So, I have finished Slender: The Arrival in about 200 minutes.I am not gonna start with ratings. No, ratings are not really my favorite thing and I do not see the point why one does have to rate every single piece of ♥♥♥♥. Most of those reviews are usually very oppinion-based, therefore, how can one take those reviews seriously (with a few exceptions, of course).So I am trying to caputre what this game actually is, following up with a conclusiong with a small insight of my own impressions.First of all, about the overall graphics in this game. It is a game developed by an indie-studio, so you may think the visuals are not really good. They look similiar to other games, though there are a few things that make it outstanding (blurry, how your character runs, the sunrays,...), so it is not a poorly designed game. The animations are stiff though.The atmosphere swaps from tense to relaxing quite often, giving the player a few breaks.Tense because if you are being haunted, you feel haunted. That is something not easily accomplished in horror games (I like to relate to Cry of Fear or Outlast). The relaxing parts are surely needed, since calming down is important - You feel your blood pumping over and over again, making this a worthy experience for someone who likes those tense experiences. I also have to mention the game gives you a few jumpscares (While I do not think they are necessairy in this game).Controls and environment in overall are simple, while rather strict. That means you can not really interact with your environment. You can not climb outside of windows, neither can you jump, or anything else like that. What you can do is focusing your flashling + zooming it in/turning it off alongside moving around and sprinting/crouching. That works suprisingly well for this game, thus not even making one miss any acrobatic or environmental interactions with your world.As you can see (or read) I tried to be mostly objective there. Finally, I would like to add a few own thought about this game though,I played this game pretty much in one go. I only died twice in the end, since it was really unclear where you had to run to and that there actually is a goal there....that is about the only real complaint I have about this game. That chapter was not really necessaire in my opinion (No, not even that boy catched me off guard).While there are few aninmations regarding the beings haunting you, the environment itself is beautifully designed. Especially the sunlight made this game unique to me, it was well implemented in this game...while the nights revealed very, very sinister feelings in me. Had me pretty hard in its grip, the atmosphere is really great.I will surely play it another time, because I missed a few collectibles (7 I think). So it is a rather short game....paying around 10 bucks for this surely is ok, although I recommend buying this one on sale. It is pretty short, with a rather low replay-value. What is really interesting though is that you play very different parts, mostly just one chapter, with people you read about in the game itself. While the end of the game is not that interesting I would say, it all fits together in the end.Thanks for reading, I will just stop here now....what?...Rating you said? Alright, 8/10

Posted: January 14, 2015
												I love hating that game.  This is more than I can handle.I watch horror movies, from gore to creepy, and I know most of the tricks.  But there is a HUGE difference between watching a movie and playing a game: the interactivity.  Suddenly, you really ARE the one to make choices.  No more hiding behind your popcorns.I did not even know that I could feel that way, and in a twisted way, I am glad that I found out.  None of my experiences so far, in real life or with movies, comes close to what I feel when I play this game.  I thought I would be strong enough to deal with all that over-hyped Slenderman meme.  I am not.  It could be Slender, it could be anything, it hardly matters, I have never felt so helpless and terrified in my entire life.  I am 36 years-old.I have not gone very far, I believe I am half-way through the second level, although it feels much more.  I pressed Escape and Exit, then turned on the lights in my living room again.  My heart beat is slowing down; I will try again, later.  Tomorrow maybe.I need a drink.

Posted: January 16, 2015
												The game remains very true to the youtube series such as Darkharvest00, EMH, marblehornets etc, which I love, as I am a huge fan of the slendy series. The settings are all very similar, and the camera overlay was a nice touch.It has a good atmosphere, with creepy sound cues and lighting. This could have been improved with more buildup of tension as seen in amnesia and in the slender vlogs, where you anticipate that something will happen around every corner. Still, the environments are well designed, and the graphics are very good, including shadows, hdr and a nice touch of colour distortion from slendy at various points in the game. The game also runs very smoothly, unlike the first game (8 pages) which had serious fps issues.The jump scares are fantastic, and really make the game. To see slendy in front of you and then turn around to find him behind you is terrifying, and is a good change from other horror games where you can just lock the door and know that you will be alerted to the monsters arrival when he tries to break it down.The proxy is a questionable addition in my opinion, and not well designed. While its good to have another enemy to run from, there seems to be no way of getting rid of her or to combat her. She will just stand there indefinetley when you point the torch at her, and when you runaway, she will suddenly appear out of nowhere behind you and kill you. Initially she is scary, but after the 5th time she gets you in a few minutes, she becomes more of an annoying obstacle than a terrifying monster. Overall, while the game does have its faults, it is still a fantastic horror game, and also a must have for any fan of the slenderman mythos and videos.

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Slender: The Arrival is the official expanded version of Slender: The Eight Pages. It meant to have a story behind why the Slender Man is after you, and a few others. What do I think of this game you may ask? Well, this review will cover that.First off, I will start with the setting and character's. The game take's place in an unspecified state of America. Most of it take's place in park with a radio tower and a mine complex. Now on to the character's. The game's protagonist is Lauren, a woman looking for her missing friend named Kate, who has recently disappeared. A man only known as CR can be read about in the in-game collectibles.He apeared to be somehow involved with Kate and the Slender Man, whom does not need an introduction.The next thing I want to cover is the overall gameplay. I think it is both good and bad. I will start the good. The atmosphere is probably the best part of the the game. It gave me an unsettling feeling throughout the game. Another great thing about The Arrival is the genuinely creepy music. It gets more and more tense as you complete the objectives. And also, not being able to fight back can also keep some people on edge.Now for the bad. Unfortunately, there are more bad aspects than you might be thinking. Let's start with the objectives. Pretty much every level involves somehow interacting with a certain amount of objects. It does'nt take very long for the game to start feeling quite repetitive. While a recent update added two new levels to branch off from this, those two levels are'nt very good and may leave quite a bit of gamers feel pretty unsatisfied after completing them. Another thing I will cover is the overall scares. They start out great, but lose their charm less than halfway through the game. The Slendern Man himself begins to dwindle as the as the game progresses. While he seems terrifying at first, he later starts to become less and less scary to the point that you can easily walk past him and not have even the slightest sense of fear. The two new enemies added also begin to have this effect. The hooded person at first seems pretty scary, but it's cheap jump scare attack becomes pretty un-scary and rather just annoying and cheaply animated. The skeletal figure is also pretty unsettling, but soon just apears to be a generic horror cliche. Another thing is the game's incredibly short length. The game can easily be finished in less than two hours, incuding the bonus level.The VerdictSlender: The Arrival simply feels rushed. The music and atmosphere are great, but the repetitive gameplay, cheap scare's, and extremely short length just ruins the experience. If you want a cheap and short horror game, buy Slender: The Arrival. If you want quality scares and fun gameplay, look elswhere.  Overall, 5/10

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Worth a play if you like creepy games. This game isn't terribly twisted or gross like a lot of horror games, it's just all about keeping your anxiety level high! Don't get me wrong, the story and atmosphere keep you creeped out, but what's really creepy is that, for much of the game, the slender man can appear anytime, anywhere, and all you can do is run as fast as you can in the opposite direction.It only takes a couple of hours to play through, if you're not trying to get 100% everything, but it's worth the ride.A negative would be that the story isn't all that interesting or coherent. Maybe it would make more sense if I 100%-ed the game and was able to read all the notes laying around, but really, a game should make sense without requiring that.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												Being a huge horror game fan, Slender was one of my favorite series of games. There was never really a GREAT Slender game, but there was also never really a terrible Slender game. Slender: The Arrival is Parsec Production's (the original creator of Slender: The Eight Pages) first attempt at a story-driven horror game. Let me say, it's definitely an experience.The story's introduction is kinda slow, but the game's pretty so its no big deal. Your friend, Kate, has been missing. You travel to her house in the middle of the forest, and when you get there, the doors are open and the house is a mess. After finding clues and her room key, you see that Kate was terrorized by something for quite some time. Obviously, there's a TON more to the story, missing children, looking for pages (of course), and you even get to play as Kate for a mission.These missions aren't always "Collect 8 Pages". Sometimes it's just looking for clues, other times you have to start generators, but I won't spoil any more.Slender: The Arrival is a spot on attempt at a horror game. I pooped myself and jumped out of my seat a couple times, and I can't wait to see what else Parsec Productions and Blue Isle have for this game or the series.9/10

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Probably the scariest game I have ever played. Don't expect complex gameplay or intense puzzle-solving or anything like that, you should just expect to wet your pants after a while. Most of the game is just spent exploring and looking to collect a set number of items (similiar to the mod this game was based off), however don't think that means this game is boring. The game developers excel in knowing how to properly f%$k your mind while you attempt to avoid being scared. I actually have difficulty playing this game for very long at once, because I get so nervous.One of the most outstanding parts of this game is its replayability. You would think that a game like this would have little to none; you would be wrong. The developers again excel at finding ways to make each playthrough unique, hiding items in different locations and having scares randomly generated during your playthrough. Just because you were safe in an area before means nothing the next playthrough!! One of the only downsides to this is that the game is a little bit more difficult than you would expect. Finding the locations of the items before getting killed (or giving up in fear of having a heart attack) can be frustrating when their locations change every time you die, however there is usually a pattern that can be discerned eventually.While this might not be the most 'fun' or 'addictive' scary game I've ever played, I would say hands-down it is the 'scariest'. I still enjoy watching my girlfriend play it and watching her scream when she turns around and slenderman is standing right behind her. If you are someone who enjoys torturing yourself through voluntary fear, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!

Posted: March 19, 2016
												(mini-review)A fun little minigame that would work well on iOS. As a PC game, despite great graphics, excellent atmosphere and some legitimate scares, the game feels superfluous. Everything you saw in the original Slender, is present here...just...prettier. The game loses its intensity as multiple villains are introduced and by the time the ending credits roll, you realize you've been roped in by excessive promises to experience a really weak ending...A scary game for the first hour.  Not much after that. Worth the purchase for 3 dollars or less. 5/10.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Slender:The Arrival had good atmosphere, and the "attacks" were well done, tense moments that occasionally startled me enough to get me to jump out of my seat a bit and get the ol' heart racing. Graphics are so-so, but sound design is well done. I am still not sure what the story was really supposed to be about, aside from a way to get you into a position to be jumped by some beasty or another. But, that is really what this is about - the scare. So, I dont regret spending 10 dollars on it, and it was fun. if short. I would have been happier paying $5, but I would still recommend it if you like a good startle and would like to spend 3-4 hours getting it. Think of it as a movie, but one that is better than most of the sub-par stuff being passed off as horror in the theater these days.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												If you liked the original 8-pages Slender, this game is for you. Some complain the story is short, and that's true. That being said, it's a good story, and it will get your adrenaline going. The story is more of a bonus, with the 8-pages (which can be played as a single game-mode at any time) still being the most exciting mode with the best re-play value. Among some of the story-mode levels, there are a few gems, such as a level that takes place in an abandoned underground mine where you must turn on a series of generators in order to escape, all while being pursued by Slender AND an unknown assailant! This level plays just like the 8-pages mode, so it' really just for more variety.My only "complaint" about this game is the seemingly random level of difficulty. Occassionally I will play a round of the 8-pages or abandoned mine level and run into Slendy and his friend at every turn, while the next round I'll find all the generators and never even see my pursuers. This is not an entirely bad thing, however, as I truly never know what to expect, and have been caught off guard too many times to recall.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												TLDRGame starts out slow, picks up quickly.  Not really jump scares, but overall constant fear.  You will almost certainly♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants in fear. 10/10 Too scared to play past part 1Let's paint a beautiful picture for the people.  You're 1987 Volvo is driving down a wooded road on the Appalachian Trail (Or somewhere along the lines of that), when all of the sudden your car loses control and slides into a tree.  Your phone isn't getting any reception and there's no other cars or buildings in sight.  You know your friend Kate's house is right down the road and so you make your way down the dusty pebbled pathway. Down this longwinded path you notice a long brick fence, and contemplate: just who exactly can afford such a fence, and who exactly are they trying to block out? For there is no other houses or population for that matter in sight.  Regardless, you wonder down this road and find a 1998 Range Rover abandoned on the path and make nothing of it whatsoever, because the only people that own Range Rover's are divorcees who ran off with their lawyers. I'm getting carried away now. You reach the end of the path and see Kate's house (Her mother's in reality) and in a remarkable 5 seconds it goes from day to night and you nonchalantly carry on with your way into her house.  It's dark, the bass is heavy and there are scribbles of trees and Slender himself on the wall.  You wonder around this dark and lustrous house in search of clues and wonder just where your friend Kate is.  Among further investigation you notice a pamphlet from Kate's mother's funeral service, as well as a letter (clue 2) talking about how weird things have been happening around the house lately and they aren't really explainable.  From there, you head outback after covering everything in the house and you'll find another clue (not disclosing its location) and off you are into the woods to help find Kate.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												Before I jump to any conclusions that the game is good or bad, I would like to say I did enjoy this game...'s story.  The game mechanics and the story are amazing. The game definitely has a kind of creepy factor to it. Plus, the art designs, and little details throughout the game are perfect. Yet, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone, other than maybe an artist who wouldn't care about the story, rather just the art. I had heard that the game was coming out on my birthday of 2013. I was excited after watching the trailer. Until I bought the game and downloaded it. The start was ok. I thought, "No action yet. But it's better to start Slender games by setting the mood, right?" And then I got to the house, and found that Slender wasn't there, just clues, and the sense of horror. I wasn't that happy that I had no adrenaline in the first 10 minutes. Then we had to go outside! I thought, "OK Here comes the scares!" I didn't see Slender for about 7 more minutes. After I did see him, we played, "Slender The Eight Pages: Better Graphics Edition"! I was not happy at all. Why should I pay $10 to have a copy of, "Slender The Eight Pages"? "Maybe they just want to start off this way!" I said slightly worried. Then we were running around a terminal with a demon girl and Slender chasing us. "Oh my gosh! I can't wait to play, 'Follow The Leader:Kind Of Scary Edition'!" I'm not here to say what is and what isn't scary, but I can guarantee you... I was only mildly creeped out by the story. Throughout the rest of the game, I was either bored.... or... bored. The ending was kind of: Meh. I actually played the game 2.5 times to see if there was any parts that I missed to make the game better, there wasn't. If I rated this game, I'd give it a 56%. Not that good.
