Posted: January 10, 2016
												Slender: The Arrival is Parsec Productions' ramped-up successor to their definitive Slender: The Eight Pages. Pairing everyone's favorite scary meme man with some fresh gameplay and writing from the crew behind the Marble Hornets series on YouTube, The Arrival provides the Slender Man with a fresh coat of paint that, in all honesty, it may not have needed.Instead of the somewhat-randomized page-grabbing romp through a dark and mysterious park that encapsulated the original Slender game, Slender: The Arrival offers much more of a narrative strung through several environments. From a suburban home to a construction (or logging? I'm not sure) site in the woods and an ever-beckoning radio tower, you're thrust into a quest to gather information on a child's disappearance and the Slender Man himself while avoiding him and several other menacing creatures along the way.I'm gonna be honest: I was never entirely sure just what I was looking for or why I was supposed to care about what was going on, save for self-preservation. Despite the Marble Hornets people penning the plot, Arrival lacked a lot of the subtle hints and well-hidden clues characteristic of their YouTube work and the expanded material around it. Or, if there was such context, most of it was easy to overlook while trying to avoid whatever was chasing me on a given level. The narrative could have been much more well-established, to say the least.It was, however, nice to stretch my legs in some new areas with Slendy riding my behind, and the last level or two before the finale did some things I thought were neat. It's also nice to know the "bonus" level, which supposedly offers a little extra backstory but mostly just lets you putz around a bit more, actually works in the PC version rather than being completely broken like the console ports.Slender: The Arrival isn't fantastic, but it isn't completely awful, either. If anything, I'd say get it on sale.

Posted: November 9, 2014
												Let's begin with this,You drive to your friends house, the house is almost pitch black aside from a few very dim lights spread across the first floor of house, one in the living room, one in the dining room, and the last in the kitchen. Thankfully you have your trusty flashlight, and your video camera. Not a sound could be heard in the entire house, you carefully walk up the stairs into the second floor, and into the last room down the hall. You walk in, and pages are scattered across the room and the window broken. you pick up one specific page that tells you to go to the woods, then you hear a loud scream coming from behind the gate in the backyard, you run to the window to investigate and see a tall slender man, standing there watching you from outside the window. as soon as you attempt to readjust your eyes, it is gone.And so we now know what we are going up against, the terror begins.Slender: The Arrival is a brilliant horror game that add's so much to what Slender: The Eight Pages lacked, a story, stunning graphics, more scares, and a whole lot more to do, with secret levels, collectibles, and fun achievements to go after. Slender is a very good horror game that brings much to the table, and on par (and possibly better) than Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs but not as involved as Amnesia: The Dark Descent. All in all, This game is definitely worth playing8/10

Posted: November 6, 2014
												If there is a game more or the same feel and atmosphere as Amnesia, as Silent Hill (along those pretty classic horror lines)...THE ARRIVAL is among those games.- First off the game has beautifully composed music, greatly developed ambient sounds, the look and feel. Even with barely anything else other than "search, collect and survive", the game never fails to disappoint or bore (how could it possibly do that?) - Helplesness is the key element here...terror is the main goal directed towards us (the player) and shocks, oh don't worry....there are aplenty.- I don't wanna spoil it for people who haven't (or are for some reason scared to play the game), but know one thing...all future buyers...if you love horror (SURVIVAL HORROR) minus the firearms and meaningless combat implemented, you will certainly love and are gonna get utterly scared (or pleased in a perverse way^^) of Slender: THE ARRIVAL. You will like it...you might love it....you are gonna JUMP from JOY of it...He's...waiting...for....you....END OF REVIEW...

Posted: January 10, 2016
												Slender: The Arrival is Parsec Productions' ramped-up successor to their definitive Slender: The Eight Pages. Pairing everyone's favorite scary meme man with some fresh gameplay and writing from the crew behind the Marble Hornets series on YouTube, The Arrival provides the Slender Man with a fresh coat of paint that, in all honesty, it may not have needed.Instead of the somewhat-randomized page-grabbing romp through a dark and mysterious park that encapsulated the original Slender game, Slender: The Arrival offers much more of a narrative strung through several environments. From a suburban home to a construction (or logging? I'm not sure) site in the woods and an ever-beckoning radio tower, you're thrust into a quest to gather information on a child's disappearance and the Slender Man himself while avoiding him and several other menacing creatures along the way.I'm gonna be honest: I was never entirely sure just what I was looking for or why I was supposed to care about what was going on, save for self-preservation. Despite the Marble Hornets people penning the plot, Arrival lacked a lot of the subtle hints and well-hidden clues characteristic of their YouTube work and the expanded material around it. Or, if there was such context, most of it was easy to overlook while trying to avoid whatever was chasing me on a given level. The narrative could have been much more well-established, to say the least.It was, however, nice to stretch my legs in some new areas with Slendy riding my behind, and the last level or two before the finale did some things I thought were neat. It's also nice to know the "bonus" level, which supposedly offers a little extra backstory but mostly just lets you putz around a bit more, actually works in the PC version rather than being completely broken like the console ports.Slender: The Arrival isn't fantastic, but it isn't completely awful, either. If anything, I'd say get it on sale.

It is short but this is Blue isle studios first major commercial game. I guess it depends on the individual player on how well this game is. Personally i think that once you get into it, play it on hard, play it a couple of thimes to get the story down then you're all set. I also think horror games should not be played on a regular basis otherwise players of the genre will be desensetized by them. Even though the arrival didn't get as much recgonition as the eight pages it still get's major recgonition for being the first and finacially successful commercial Slender man game. It gets and 8.7/10 rating in my book. :D

Posted: December 25, 2016
												Slender is a beautiful and intense experience. The atmosphere is really nostalgic, intriguing and remind me of those 80s movies, when a good story really touched your guts and when we use to jump in out seats, to feel as if you had experience everyting that happen, when movies were, somehow, as reales experiences. Slender is very detail oriented, and most of the information and the background story is given in a very smart and indirect way There is the dynamics of looking for pages, and walk several times through the same places, but it doesnt matter, because its part of the agony of being followed by something evil that may have captured your friend... so you can only move forward. The game is short, though, you can have it finish in less than an hour, but it took me 4 hours my first time. Its a game I will play again, definitly, and its one of those experiences, as the 80s movies, that makes feel as if they have told me something profund.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												The most stunning part of SLENDER: The Arrival, is the visual improvement from it's predecessor, SLENDER: The Eight Pages. As a potential triple A title, the visuals enhance the horror aspects of the classic slender experience. A full fledged story keeps you invested in characters and progressing overall, but without taking away tension and suspense when actually playing through the game. The animation and soundtrack are just as suspenseful, keeping me on my toes and ready to throw my headphones off my head in time for a jumpscare.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												It's very hard to like this game. That's why I don't. Slender: The Arrvival is a short game which I payed £15 for. That was about £5. When I say short, I mean short. A campaign which can take under 20 minutes to complete, the game is filled with missions which all add up to about 1 hour of gameplay. Unfortunately, your given little knowledge of how to activate some of them. For example, the scariest chapter in the game, Homestead, can be played by clicking on the TV screen after playing a recording in which you play as the main charaters Mother. Most of the Chapters are pretty short as too. If your looking for a scare then this is the game to buy. I genuinly♥♥♥♥♥♥myself playing this game. It is an excellent blend of jumpscares, atmosphere, and a truly-terrifying story. The mission where you play as Charlie as a child undoubtedly disturbed me. However, if your looking for a fun horror game, then you should probrably look for another game. The gameplay is sticky and unevenly paced, and the scares mask over any type of enjoyment for the light-hearted. But out of all of this, the worst part of this game is each of the 3 endings. For players who bought the game without Steam, the game ends in the radio tower when you get jumped byCharlie. On the Steam version, the game advances to an old burnt down barn I had previously visited in the game. This is by for the best ending in the game.Unfortunately, it's all about waiting, but it does reveal the rest of the story. Within 5 minutes of this scary atmosphere, you die and.... game over.However, the final ending, which is activated by playing through the game in Hardcore mode, is so bad it's hilarious. For some reason the your character jumps off the radio tower and, dies. Yep, that's it.My personal review is a 5/10, because of how inconsistent the game actually is. It is far too overrated.
